I wandered where the marsh grasses grow,
And shadows danced in silver dew.
A lantern flickered, frail and low,
Its glow a secret it never knew.
The trees stood hushed, as if in prayer,
And stars were veiled in drifting air.
I heard a name—my own—softly called,
Not loud, but deep, as if from stone.
No footprints marked the path I crawled,
Just frost and moss and sighing bone.
Then silence, thick and absolute,
And time collapsed beneath my boot.
I woke at dawn with frost on cheek,
No memory, just the will to speak.
Now every dusk, I strain to hear
That voice that rose from earth so near.
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
But still it breathes beneath the snow.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I met a child with eyes of coal,
Who stood where icy river currents flow,
And asked me to reclaim my soul.
No moon, no stars, just fog and dread,
Yet fireflies pulsed in ghostly red.
The child said nothing, just held a key,
Rusted and warm, carved out from me.
I reached—but thunder cracked the sky,
And when I blinked, the child was gone.
Just hoofprints melted into mud and lie,
And a lullaby half-sung, half-drawn.
Years passed, and still I dream that place,
A hollow carved by time and grace.
Sometimes I hear the key turn slow,
In locks I lost so long ago.
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
But echoes never truly go.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I walked a road of ash and pine,
The air so still, the world below
Seemed frozen in a breathless sign.
No sound but crickets, faint and thin,
And something moving deep within.
A house appeared with windows black,
No light, yet shadows moved out back.
I called out—twice—but no reply,
Just crows that rose like smoke in flight.
Then laughter, soft, a lullaby,
That chilled me deeper than the night.
I ran until my lungs gave way,
And slept beneath a dying day.
Now every storm recalls that tune,
That house, that silence, that soft moon.
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
Yet still I feel its presence grow.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I found a letter sealed in wax,
Addressed to me, but I didn’t know
The hand that wrote, or what it lacks.
I broke the seal with trembling hands,
The ink was red, like shifting sands.
It spoke of love, of debts unpaid,
Of vows beneath a crooked shade.
A name was written—mine, but not—
As if I’d lived another life.
A knock came then—three quiet shots—
I dropped the page, gripped by such strife.
When I looked up, the fire died,
And snow had fallen, deep and wide.
No house, no door, no path, no trace,
Just that cursed script upon the place.
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
But some truths never let you go.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I followed footsteps not my own,
Through tangled wood where brambles grow,
And roots twist deep in marrowed stone.
They led to where a well stood bare,
Its mouth agape with silent prayer.
I peered inside—no water gleamed,
But eyes looked up, or so it seemed.
A hand reached out, not to attack,
But beckon, slow, with quiet grace.
I stepped back—earth began to crack—
And vanished without leaving trace.
I ran until the forest cleared,
And woke—my hair had turned to white.
Now every night, the dream repeats,
Those steps, that well, those voiceless treats.
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
But still it pulls me down below.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

responses.text:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When moonlight fled and stars burned low,
I wandered paths of ancient stone,
Through whispering woods I faced alone.

The wind, a hush of hidden breath,
Spoke secrets older than my death.
A lantern flickered, frail and thin,
Its glow a ghost from deep within.

I saw a figure, cloaked in gray,
Who beckoned me to come away.
We walked where time forgot to tread,
Where dreams lie buried, cold and dead.

No clock could mark that timeless place,
No sun restore the soul’s lost grace.
We spoke of love and loss and fear,
Of every hope that died right here.

And when at last I turned to go,
The lantern dimmed, the shadows grow.
Now each night since, I feel the call—
One dark, dark night that haunts us all.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
The earth was wrapped in frost and snow.
I stood beneath a hollow tree,
Where something watched and let me be.

It didn’t speak, it didn’t move,
But in its eyes, I saw my love—
A face I’d lost, a name I’d sworn
To carry through the years now torn.

The wind stirred soft, a breath, a sigh,
As if the dead could still reply.
And for a moment, just a breath,
I held her close, defying death.

But time is cruel, and dawn will rise,
And steal the truth from dreaming eyes.
I woke alone, the sky turned gray,
Yet still I long to go that way.

One dark, dark night—it calls to me,
A memory or mystery?
I cannot say, I only know:
It was long ago… and yet it’s so.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When rivers ran with silver glow.
A child I was, with bare feet cold,
Chasing echoes down the old.

The hills hummed songs of distant wars,
Of sailors lost and broken doors.
An owl called once, a mournful sound,
As if the sky were breaking ground.

I found a box beneath a root,
With letters tied in faded soot.
They spoke of war, of love, of flight,
Of someone lost to endless night.

I read them all beneath the moon,
And wept for sorrows not my own.
Then buried them where none would see,
A secret kept eternally.

Now years have passed, I’m old and slow,
But still that night begins to show—
In dreams I dig, the box appears,
And floods my soul with ancient tears.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
But in my heart, it burns below.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I walked where silence learned to grow.
No stars, no moon, no guiding light,
Just footsteps lost in endless night.

The trees stood still like frozen guards,
Their branches drawn like jagged shards.
I called a name—I can’t recall—
But something answered from the wall

Of mist that rose from unseen streams,
And shaped itself from broken dreams.
It wore my face, but older, worn,
As if by grief and time outshorn.

It said, ‘You’ll come back here again,
To live the loss, to know the pain.
Each night you sleep, you walk this way,
Until you learn to face the day.’

Then vanished like a dying spark.
I woke within my narrow dark.
But still I fear when lights are low—
One dark, dark night… I always go.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I watched a village buried in snow.
No footprints marked the frozen lanes,
No laughter danced through window panes.

A dog howled once from some distant shed,
Then silence fell, thick and dead.
I knocked on doors, I called each name,
But no one answered, none the same.

The chimneys cold, the hearths all black,
As if the world had gone off track.
I found a diary left ajar,
Its pages stained as if with war.

It told of dreams that turned to dread,
Of voices whispering, ‘Join the dead.’
One by one, they walked outside,
Drawn by the storm, the freezing tide.

I closed the book, I fled the place,
But still I see that ghostly face—
In every shadow, every glow,
One dark, dark night… so long ago.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text:
Fire: a tongue of gold that licks the night,
Whispering secrets in a flickering light.
It dances reckless on the timber’s bone,
A wild heart pulsing, crackling, overgrown.
Born of a spark, it swells with ancient breath,
Devouring silence, dancing close to death.
It paints the shadows, long and lean and sly,
And casts the stars down from the ashen sky.
Not kind, not cruel—just hunger, pure and vast,
A fleeting kingdom built to fade too fast.
It warms the hands that cower in the cold,
Yet claims the forests, reckless, uncontrolled.
Oh, fire, you keeper of both gift and pyre,
You are the ghost of every lost desire.

Fire: the first word shouted into dark,
The pulse beneath the skin of the lark,
The anger in the mountain’s molten core,
The knock upon death’s unyielding door.
You leap from flint with fury and surprise,
A serpentine god with ever-hungry eyes.
You curl around logs like a lover’s hand,
Then turn to ash what once you understand.
You are the hearth where stories take their form,
The candle fighting through a coming storm.
You are the torch raised in rebellion’s name,
The pyre where love surrenders into flame.
Neither savior nor destroyer, but both, entwined—
A mirror held to the chaos in the mind.

Fire: a spark in the void, a sudden red eye,
Winking at darkness as time rushes by.
You leap from nothing, a gasp in the air,
A sudden presence beyond all compare.
You twist and you twirl in a fevered delight,
Casting long phantoms in pale, jumping light.
You sing in crackles, a language unknown,
A voice from the roots of the world, overgrown.
You warm the wanderer lost in the snow,
Yet leave only embers where forests once grow.
Oh, flame, you are memory, passion, and fear—
A moment of brilliance that vanishes near.
You are life’s brief flare against endless night,
A shout in the void: I was here. I was bright.

Fire: the sun’s lost child, fallen to earth,
A fragment of chaos given brief worth.
You writhe in the grate with a serpentine grace,
A wild, golden beast in a small, bounded space.
You consume the dry wood with a hungry kiss,
A lover that turns all it touches to miss.
You glow in the eyes of the midnight wolf’s stare,
And burn in the hearts of those drowning in care.
You forged the first tool, lit the first song,
Guided the lost when the path was all wrong.
But you also rise with a vengeful hand,
A storm from the reach of a scorched, barren land.
Fire, you are balance—creation and pyre,
Both the question and answer lit by desire.

Fire: a whisper that grows to a roar in the air,
A crown of gold flames crowned with despair.
You spiral upward, defying the ground,
A voice without words in a crackling sound.
You glow in the chest of the poet’s last line,
And burn in the veins of the rebel’s design.
You are the blush on the lover’s shy cheek,
And the war that reduces the strong to the weak.
You dance in the candle at midnight’s soft hush,
And blaze through the city in violent rush.
You are both the cradle and coffin of light,
A paradox burning through day and through night.
Oh, fire, eternal in passion and pyre,
You are the soul’s echo: desire, desire.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text:
Fire: a tongue of gold in the throat of night,
Licking shadows from the walls with hungry light.
It dances on the hearth, a whispered hymn,
Crumbling logs to ash with fevered limb.
It speaks in crackles, ancient and wise,
Of suns devoured and starless skies.
It warms the hands that dare to near,
Yet claims the fool who holds it dear.
In ember-glow, lost faces gleam—
Lovers, warriors, fading dream.
Oh, fire, both cradle and pyre,
Bearer of both desire and dire.
You forge the sword and burn the scroll,
Keeper of secrets, devourer of soul.
A spark can birth you, a breath can kill—
Fragile monarch on a throne of still.
Yet in your blaze, the darkness dies,
A fleeting god with mortal eyes.

Fire: the first word the world ever knew,
Spoken in lightning, bold and new.
It carved the cave, it shaped the tool,
Turned trembling beast to roasted fuel.
It gathered tribes in rings of gold,
Stories spun as flames took hold.
It forged the plow, it lit the page,
Defied the dark from age to age.
Now it flickers in screens and wires,
Still feeding dreams, still stoking fires.
Not just destruction, though that's true—
It warms the bread, it melts the dew.
It lives in chests where passions burn,
In every heart that dares return
To love, to fight, to start once more,
Though scorched before, though bruised and sore.
Fire: not just end, but genesis,
The spark behind all we confess.
A whisper, a roar, a guiding star—
We are the kindling. We burn, we are.

Fire: a child’s match struck on stone,
A tiny sun all his own.
It trembles, bright, against the air,
A moment of magic, crisp and rare.
Then—gone. A wisp of smoke ascends,
Where wonder briefly made amends
For all the world’s cold, heavy gray.
He strikes again. It lights the way.
Not just for feet, but for the mind,
A spark of courage, hard to find.
Fire teaches quick, then fades to black,
Leaves only memory on the track.
Yet in that flash, a truth takes hold:
Even the smallest light can scold
The endless night. So light another,
Feed the flame, its bonds to sunder.
For every spark that dares to fly
Is defiance flung at the sky.
Fire: brief, bright, and fiercely free—
A poem written in energy.

Fire: the wound that glows in silence,
A pulse beneath the skin’s defiance.
Not in the hearth, but in the chest,
Where love once burned and would not rest.
Now embers smolder, low and deep,
Secrets the soul no longer keeps.
It chars the edges of a name,
Whispers a ghost of sudden flame.
You stir the ash with trembling hand,
Seeking warmth you can’t command.
It flares—then fades. A hollow pyre.
The heart recalls what fire required:
Fuel, faith, the breath of trust.
Now only smoke remains in gust.
Yet still it burns, this quiet blaze,
Through silent nights and clouded days.
Not seen, but felt. A constant pyre.
Fire: the soul’s unquenched desire.

Fire: the signal on the hill,
A call to climb, to stand still
Against the wind, the rain, the fear—
Proof that someone’s still out here.
It flickers, fights the swallowing dark,
A single, stubborn, blazing spark.
No grand conflagration, just a plea:
I am alive. I see. I be.
It draws no crowds, it feeds no forge,
Just marks a soul that won’t submerge.
It says: though broken, bent, and scarred,
I carry light. I’ve come this far.
And if you see it, far and dim,
Know you are not alone in him.
One flame inspires another’s breath—
A chain of fire conquering death.
So light your own, however small,
Let it rise, let it call.
For fire shared will never tire—
Fire: the soul’s one true empire.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text:
Fire: a tongue of gold licks the night,
Dancing in flickers, wild and bright.
It hums an ancient, crackling song,
A force both fleeting and lifelong.
Born from a spark, a whispered breath,
It defies the silence, defies cold death.
It warms the hands, it lights the soul,
Yet in its heart, a hunger rolls.
It paints the shadows on the wall,
A puppet master, captivating all.
One moment tender, soft, and low,
The next, a tempest, fierce and aglow.
It consumes the dry, the old, the worn,
Emerging, transformed, a phoenix reborn.
Ashes drift like grey snow down,
Marking where the bright flames frown.
A paradox in embered guise—
Creation born from where it dies.
Fire: destroyer, keeper, guide,
A restless spirit, burning wide,
A fleeting beauty, fierce and stark,
A fleeting echo in the dark.

Fire: a whisper in the dry grass,
A spark that time cannot surpass.
It starts so small, a timid glow,
Then swallows fields it longs to know.
A serpent slithering through the brush,
Leaving behind a blackened hush.
It climbs the trees with orange claws,
Igniting bark and splintered jaws.
No rain can calm its hungry breath,
No plea can alter its dance with death.
It paints the sky in choking red,
A crown of smoke above the dead.
It sings a song of heat and dread,
A chorus where the living fled.
And when it tires, when flames subside,
It leaves the earth in scorched divide.
But in the ash, a seed may wake,
New green from ruin, for nature's sake.
Fire: cruel teacher, harsh and wise,
Beneath indifferent, watching skies.

Fire: the hearth's soft, golden eye,
Where shadows shrink and laughter fly.
It crackles low, a lullaby,
Beneath a vast and starless sky.
Kettles sing, and stories bloom,
In its warm, flickering, gentle gloom.
A cup of tea, a book well-loved,
All lit and warmed, all gently shoved
Into a moment, safe and deep,
Where weary thoughts and worries sleep.
It paints the walls with dancing light,
Transforming night to soft twilight.
No fury here, no wild display,
Just steady warmth to light the way.
A silent friend, a constant flame,
That whispers peace without a name.
Fire: the quiet, kind embrace,
That time and cold cannot erase.

Fire: a signal in the night,
A beacon blazing, sharp and bright.
It calls the lost, the cold, the far,
Guiding wanderers like a star.
It speaks in pulses, red and clear,
A language only some can hear.
Not just for warmth or cooked repast,
But coded light from ages past.
A mountain peak, a desert plain,
It breaks the dark, dispels the rain
Of fear that falls on lonely souls.
It marks the place where safety rolls
Like waves upon a distant shore.
One spark can say, 'I am here. More
Than embers live. Come, join the light.'
It turns the void to shared insight.
Fire: the wordless, blazing call
That unites strangers, one and all.

Fire: a god with shifting face,
Both gift and curse, both time and space.
It forged the blade, it lit the cave,
It danced within the warrior's grave.
It powers engines, lights the street,
Makes bread rise warm, makes lovers meet.
Yet in its core, a lawless core,
It takes, consumes, demands, and roars.
It doesn't care for right or wrong,
It simply burns, relentless, strong.
It shaped the world with molten hand,
And scours clean what won't withstand.
A primal force, beyond control,
That feeds the sun and lights the coal.
Fire: the pulse in every vein,
The spark behind both joy and pain,
A wild heart beating in the stone—
We harness it, but not our own.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text:
Fire: a tongue of gold that licks the night,
Devouring shadows with fierce, hungry light.
It dances reckless on the timber’s bone,
A whispered secret turned to crackling groan.
Born of a spark, a breath, a careless spark,
It climbs the air in spirals, bold and dark.
It sings in embers, hums in glowing coal,
A story ancient, written in the soul.
It warms the hands of lovers, breaks the cold,
And guards the tales that elders once have told.
Yet in its heart, a danger softly breathes,
A force that conquers, conquers, then leaves.
Ash falls like snow where once the flames had soared,
A silence deeper than the night ignored.
But from the black, a seed may yet take hold—
For fire destroys to make the new unfold.

Fire: a pulse beneath the skin of dusk,
A sudden flare where silence used to husk.
The wind leans in to taste its orange breath,
And time itself draws closer, close to death.
It paints the clouds in hues of rust and flame,
A fleeting god with neither guilt nor name.
It leaps, it laughs, it licks the overhanging bough,
Then winks away—its vow made now to howl.
It knows no mercy, has no need to speak,
Yet in its glow, the lonely find the meek.
A campfire’s ring, a candle’s trembling tear,
All echo flames that conquered ancient fear.
Oh, fire, you thief, you cradle, you bright pyre,
You lift the dark with wild, consuming wire.
And when you fade, you leave behind a prayer—
Not gone, but changed, like souls laid bare.

Fire: a word that hisses in the air,
A warning carved in smoke and sudden glare.
It leaps from match to paper, thin and dry,
And swallows memory in a golden sigh.
It curls around the photograph, the book,
Erasing love with embered, hungry look.
No siren sings when fire begins its art,
It works in silence, tearing world apart.
And yet, it bakes the bread, it forges steel,
It makes the forge where destinies congeal.
It warms the cave, it lights the astronaut’s way,
A dual force that both creates and slays.
So bless the flame, but never trust its grace—
It loves too fiercely, burns the holding place.

Fire: a spark behind the eyelid’s veil,
A thought too hot to linger, bound to fail.
It blooms in chests when passion overflows,
When love or rage in crimson current grows.
It doesn’t ask, it simply starts to burn,
A lesson taught in ash and smoke and turn.
It melts the ice of years with single breath,
And resurrects what once was close to death.
Not just the blaze that climbs the chimney tall,
But quiet fires that never show at all—
The ones that write, that fight, that dare, that dream,
That feed the soul with more than what it seems.
So strike the flint. Let courage be your guide.
Let fire rise, and light the other side.

Fire: a crack, a pop, a leap,
A rhythm low that rocks the deep.
It flickers on the cave wall’s face,
And time forgets its hurried pace.
It draws the wolf, it draws the sage,
It writes its code on every page
Of human life, from spear to star—
We are who we are because we are
Drawn to flame, its heat, its glow,
The primal truth we’ve come to know.
It cooks our meat, it shapes our steel,
It makes the night a place we feel
Alive, connected, unafraid,
Though one misstep could leave us frayed.
So praise the fire, both fierce and kind—
The oldest friend of humankind.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text:
Fire: a tongue of gold in the throat of night,
Licking shadows from the walls with hungry light.
It hums a hymn older than words or bone,
A pulse in the dark, a seed once alone.
Born of friction, a spark’s brief cry,
Now dancing wild beneath a soot-stained sky.
It braids the wind, it whispers and roars,
Unfurling stories behind closed doors.
It warms the hands that shiver in frost,
And claims the timber that time has lost.
In embers, memories curl and fade,
Like promises whispered, then unmade.
Fire: destroyer, keeper, guide,
A flicker that dares the dark to hide.
It sings of passion, of rage, of birth,
A fleeting god upon the earth.
And when it dies to a breathless glow,
It leaves behind what we used to know—
Ashes like snow on a silent floor,
And the ghost of a flame we can’t ignore.

Fire: a whisper that swells to a scream,
A molten dream in a copper stream.
It climbs the wood with fingers of flame,
Calling each shadow by its true name.
No longer silent, the hearth now sings,
As cinders burst into winged things.
It licks the air with a hungry grace,
Painting the walls with its shifting face.
Once, it warmed clans beneath open stars,
Now it flickers in TVs and cars.
But deep in veins, the old spark stays—
In lovers’ glances, in riotous days.
It burns in poets who cannot sleep,
In promises buried too deep to keep.
Fire: not just ember, not just heat,
But pulse in the soil, in heartbeats.
It waits in stone, in dormant coal,
For the spark of will to re-engage the soul.
So strike the match, let the bright truth start—
Fire lives not in wood, but in the heart.

Fire: a jagged scar across the sky,
When lightning splits the world and asks why.
It races through pines with reckless glee,
A golden fury no stream can free.
It crackles secrets the forest knew,
Turns ancient oaks to charcoal hue.
Yet from the black, green shoots arise,
Reborn from smoke, beneath new skies.
Fire: not only end, but seed,
A brutal mercy, a necessary deed.
It clears the choked, the weak, the old,
Makes room for stories yet untold.
Like passion that burns a stagnant life,
Or anger that cuts through fear and strife.
It shapes the land, it tempers steel,
Makes broken hearts begin to heal.
For what is forged in flame’s cruel test
Emerges stronger from the unrest.
So do not curse the rising glow—
Sometimes, to live, one must let go.

Fire: a flicker in the palm of a child,
A matchstick dream, reckless and wild.
It leaps to paper, then to the floor,
A spreading hunger we can’t ignore.
Sirens wail as the columns rise,
Painting the dusk with orange lies.
Brick and beam bow to its decree,
A monument turned to debris.
Yet in the crowd, eyes wide and bright,
Are drawn to destruction’s hypnotic light.
For fire reveals what walls conceal—
The love-notes burned, the wounds made real.
It strips the façade, leaves truth exposed,
Like grief that cannot be re-closed.
Fire: confessor, thief, and sage,
Writing its truth on every stage.
It takes, it shows, it purges, clears,
And in its wake, the future nears.
Not all that burns is meant to die—
Sometimes, the soul needs open sky.

Fire: a campfire’s laugh in the mountain air,
Roasting marshmallows with sticky care.
It pops and sings a simple tune,
Beneath a blanket of silver moon.
Children lean in, eyes wide and gold,
As tales of dragons and knights unfold.
The flames weave magic in smoky strands,
Held in the circle of eager hands.
It sparks the joke, the shared delight,
The quiet moment when souls feel right.
No need for screens or neon glow—
Just firelight on faces we know.
It binds the tribe, the far and near,
With warmth that conquers every fear.
Fire: the first friend humankind knew,
A dancing guest in the midnight’s view.
And though our world runs on colder power,
We still seek that primal, flickering flower.
For deep within, where instincts start,
We’re drawn to fire—and each other’s heart.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text:
Fire: a tongue of gold licks the night’s dark skin,
burning secrets into ash and shadow.
It dances with no partner, yet never alone,
its voice a crackling hymn of ancient sorrow.
In its glow, memories curl like paper edges,
lovers whisper vows soon forgotten,
and warriors sharpen blades with trembling hands.
Fire does not judge—it only consumes.
It sings of beginnings forged in destruction,
of phoenixes dreaming beneath the cinder.
Even stars are just distant fires, weary and wise,
reminding us that light is born from sacrifice.
I stare into its heart and see my own hunger,
a quiet blaze behind ribs of bone.
What will I burn to keep myself warm?
What will remain when the flames finally sleep?
Fire: not an end, but a conversation
between darkness and the courage to illuminate.

Fire: the first word spoken in the cave of time,
a syllable of light against the cold.
It taught us to cook our fears,
to gather close and tell stories of monsters
that lived just beyond the circle of safety.
Now we light candles for the dead,
and bonfires for joy, still huddled,
still afraid of what the dark might remember.
Fire does not care for our rituals.
It licks the logs with reckless joy,
then vanishes, leaving only smoke
and the scent of what once was.
Yet we strike matches like prayers,
believing in brief, bright control.
Oh, fire—fierce and fleeting teacher—
you remind us that warmth demands surrender,
that every light casts a deeper shadow,
and even the smallest spark
holds the memory of the sun.

Fire: a red eye winking through the pines,
smoke threading the wind like a warning.
Somewhere, a house exhales its history—
photos, letters, a child’s stuffed bear,
all turning into breathless grey.
Fire doesn’t hate. It doesn’t love.
It simply answers the call of air and fuel,
its hunger older than guilt.
We built gods from its power,
learned to smelt iron, to forge names into steel.
But tonight, it dances on dry grass,
uninvited, unrepentant.
And I stand at the edge of its glow,
ash on my lips, wondering
if creation and ruin
are just two names for the same flame.

Fire: a match struck in the hollow of night,
its brief life a rebellion against silence.
Yellow tip, blue heart—
a miniature sun born in a breath.
It trembles, then steadies,
lighting the edges of a face, a letter, a lie.
How easily we summon such power,
how quickly we forget its appetite.
This flame could clear a forest,
or warm a frozen hand.
It does not choose—it only burns.
And when the match dies,
it leaves behind a curl of smoke
and the scent of sulfur,
like a secret whispered too late.
Fire: neither promise nor threat,
but a truth we can hold,
briefly,
in open palms.

Fire: the pulse beneath autumn’s skin,
where leaves turn crimson and fall to cinder.
It sleeps in stone, wakes in storm,
leaps from tree to tree with electric grace.
Not evil, not holy—just alive,
consuming what the wind has dried.
It clears the underbrush of years,
makes room for green to return.
In its wake, charred earth steams,
seeds split open, dreaming of bloom.
Fire: the world’s oldest reset button,
scorched hymnal, fierce midwife.
We fear its roar, but the forest thanks it.
Even our hearts know this law:
some things must burn
so that others may breathe.

Each mile a step, each stop a verse
in poems written on the way.

No drumroll marks this grand escape,
no spotlight on the platform’s edge.
Yet something stirs—a quiet spark—
as childhood dreams and duties pledge.
The future hums beneath the floor,
the past recedes with every start.
And though the journey’s long and slow,
it moves with purpose, soul, and art.

Steam fades into the pale dawn light,
platforms humming with quiet grace.
A child yawns, a dog barks twice,
the world adjusts to morning’s pace.
You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs—
a murmur in the waiting crowd,
a flutter deep beneath the hearts.

No grand parade, no flashing signs,
just motion finding its true tone.
The rails, like nerves, begin to spark,
conducting dreams from zone to zone.
A farmer heads to market town,
a nurse returns from overnight.
Each seat a stage, each face a tale,
embraced by morning’s gentle light.

The city thins, the fields expand,
the rhythm steadies, smooth and warm.
The journey isn’t just the miles,
but every soul escaping norm.
And as the sun climbs overhead,
the train, a vessel full of starts,
still carries that first breath of joy—
when silence cracked and moved our hearts.

Now here you are, with quiet grace,

So yes, we've met before, I'm sure,

Now standing close, the air grows thin,

So yes, we've met before, it's clear,

We have met before, I swear,
In laughter, tears, and quiet prayer.
Not in this world, perhaps, but one

A village by a river wide,
Or on a cliff where eagles cried,
We spoke in tongues of flame and root,
And danced in robes of silver boot.
Or maybe we were sailors bold,
On seas of stories never told,
Our hands worn rough, our hearts alight,

Now here, in modern garb and pace,

A poet, beggar, king, or sage,
We’ve lived a thousand lives and age.
And still, despite the years between,

So yes, we’ve met before, it’s true,
In every life, in me and you.
And when this world has turned to dust,

We have met before, in passing thought,
A flicker in the corner of my mind,

Not in a life I can recall,

Where shadows rise and meanings fall,
And life and death resemble death.
Perhaps as notes in one long song,
Or waves that rise and merge as one,
We touched where time has no place, long,

Or maybe in a dream I lost,

Beneath a sky of charcoal skies.
Now here, in flesh and bone and time,
I feel the echo, soft and low,
A rhythm older than a rhyme,
A seed that only love can grow.
So yes, we've met before, I know,
In silence, in the space between,
And every time our paths will go
Through endless worlds, and still be seen.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

Was it in Rome? Or older still,

I cannot say, I only know

We have met before, I swear,

You wore a coat of faded blue,

Perhaps we were not man and friend,

I’ve seen your shadow in the rain,

So when you smile, I do not start—

We have met before, or so it seems,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

responses.text:
I saw an old cottage of clay,
Its walls bowed low with time’s decay,
Where ivy crept through shattered pane,
And silence lived in every stone.
A hearth once warm now held the rain,
Its embers gone, its stories known
Only to winds that moan and stray
Through doorways cracked and overgrown.

A kettle hung, rust-cloaked and still,

The garden, choked by thistle and will,
Forgot the touch of human brush.
Yet in the eaves, a swallow’s trill
Recalled the days of gentle rush—
Of bread baked soft, of children’s fill,
Of love that built a life from dust.

Now moonlight drapes the roof of clay,
And dreams return in pale ballet.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Sunk into earth like a buried prayer,
Its roof a sigh of moss and thatch,
Its windows blind with years of dust.
No footpath led, no gate stood near—
Just brambles guarding what was lost.

Perhaps a weaver lived within,
Her loom now stilled, her threads undone,
Or some lone sage who marked the stars
And whispered names to passing clouds.
The kettle on the cold hearth sings
A song of absence, faint and long.

Time kneads the walls like pliant dough,
And slowly, softly, pulls them down.
Yet in the cracks, small flowers grow,
Bright defiance crowned with dew—
Proof that beauty learns to stay
Even when all else fades away.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And felt the weight of yesterday.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Where shadows stretched at close of day,
Its timbers bent, its chimney gone,
Its garden lost to creeping green.
No smoke arose, no voice called out—
Just rustling leaves, a crow’s harsh cry.

I stepped inside on creaking floor,
Where dust lay thick as winter snow,
And found a chair beside the stone,
As if someone had just stepped out.
A cup, half-chipped, upon the sill,
Still held the ghost of morning tea.

The walls, once warm with laughter’s sound,
Now echoed back a hollow tune.
But in the corner, faint and low,
A lullaby the breezes knew—
Sung not in words, but in the sway
Of vines that hugged the cottage tight.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And left my silence as I passed.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Its bones half-swallowed by the hill,
A roof of reeds and quiet decay,
Where time had paused against its will.
No name remained above the door,
No trace of who had lived and loved,
Just footprints blurred upon the floor,
And doves above, softly cooed.

The hearth held ashes, cold and deep,
Like memories buried under years.
The wind would come, and secrets keep,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

responses.text:
Beneath a sky of ashen velvet, stars blink cold,
They lower him into the earth’s quiet hold.
No dawn to soften, no sun to intrude—
Only the hush of a grief-struck wood.

Candles flicker like ghosts in the air,
Whispering names to the weightless, the spare.
A raven calls once, then takes silent flight,
As shadows gather to keep watch tonight.

No hymns are sung, just the wind’s low moan,
Carrying seeds of a love overgrown.
We stand in silence, our faces drawn pale,
While night drapes its shroud on the winding trail.

The moon, a sliver, observes from afar,
A silver witness to who we are:
Fleeting, fragile, beneath its gaze,
Marking time in a world of haze.

And when the last spade turns soil to stone,
We carry the dark back to homes now lone.
For night funerals bury more than the dead—
They plant the roots of the tears we’ll shed.

Night funeral—lanterns bow their heads,
Like mourners kneeling for the last words unsaid.
Cypress trees stand sentinel and tall,
Their fingers tangled in the weeping wall.

The coffin glides on shoulders slow,
A rhythm of sorrow, a measured woe.
No drum, no brass, just breath held tight,
And footsteps fading into the night.

The earth is damp, the air is thin,
A world suspended beneath the skin
Of darkness stitched with silver thread—
A moon half-alive, the stars half-dead.

We speak no eulogy, we break no bread,
Just stand as shadows where silence is fed.
And when the grave is sealed and still,
We carry the hush up every hill.

For night funerals are not for the gone,
But for those who wake to a world undone.
They mark the hour when light withdrew,
And left us a sky of endless blue—
Not bright, but bruised, and deeply true.

They buried him when the world turned gray,
Not with gold, but with dusk’s soft fray.
The crickets paused, the wind withdrew—
As if the night knew what we’d do.

No flowers bloomed, no bells were rung,
Just the creak of wood where he was hung
In memory, in quiet, in sacred trust,
Returned to dust, returned to dust.

A single match lit a widow’s face,
Reflecting loss, a hollowed space.
She said his name, just once, so low,
It melted into the afterglow.

The soil fell like a whispered prayer,
Each clod a weight, each breath a care.
Above, the clouds began to thin,
Revealing stars that had always been.

This night funeral, solemn, deep,
Is where the living learn to sleep
With ghosts beneath the cypress trees,
And dreams that drift on midnight seas.

For when the world is wrapped in shade,
The soul is neither lost nor made—
But walks the edge where dark meets dawn,
Still wearing love like a tattered shawl drawn.

The night held its breath as they carried him down,
Past roots and stones, through sacred ground.
No sun to judge, no day to lie—
Just truth in shadow, beneath the sky.

A mother wept without a sound,
Her tears absorbed by the hallowed mound.
A child held tight to a coat too wide,
Eyes wide with dreams they could not hide.

The priest spoke words like falling ash,
Brief and brittle, quick to crash
Into the silence that followed close,
A shadow trailing where no one goes.

They lit no pyre, they sang no song,
But hummed a tune that felt all wrong
For joy, for peace, for sweet release—
It was grief’s own, raw, quiet lease.

And when the dirt sealed off the lid,
The night exhaled. The stars forbade
The dawn to come too quick, too bright—
Let sorrow rule the edge of night.

For night funerals are not for show,
But for hearts that break too deep to know
If love survives when light is gone—
If memory lasts when all is drawn
Into the hush, the deep, the done,
Beneath the moon’s unblinking sun.

Under a quilt of cloud and coal,
They laid him down to claim the role
Of silence keeper, earth’s deep guest,
Where moonlight dares not linger long.

No bugle cried, no flags were drawn,
Just breaths that trembled, soft and long.
The trees leaned in with leafy ears,
To catch the weight of unshed tears.

A lantern swung from trembling hand,
Casting shapes no one could name—
Grief, perhaps, or guilt, or grace,
Or love that time cannot erase.

The shovel scraped like bone on stone,
A sound that chilled the marrow, known
To those who’ve watched the light depart,
And felt the hollow in the heart.

Night funerals don’t end at graves,
They follow like relentless waves—
In dreams, in echoes, in the stair,
In empty chairs, in morning air.

And when the world resumes its pace,
One soul remains in that still space,
Where darkness cradles what is lost,
And love becomes its own kind of ghost.

just nettles and the scent of pine.

The wind recalls your whispered fame,
then carries it away.
You join the ones the world forgot,
down where the quiet waters run.
The night, in seamless mourning, not

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

responses.text:
Beneath a shroud of moonless sky, the night funeral begins,

This is not an end, but a soft goodbye,

Under the hush of the midnight hue,

Night funeral—no sun dares intrude,

The earth breathes slow beneath frost-touched grass,

We gather not with wails or tears,

A body wrapped in linen white,

No flowers bloom in this cold embrace,

Beneath the soil, the worms will sing

We leave no stone, we carve no name,

In darkness, death is not alone—

The wind hums low, a sacred tune,
Beneath the gaze of the silver moon.
And when the dawn begins to stir,
We vanish—like smoke from a dying hearth’s blur.

The night funeral unfolds in hush,
A breath held deep, a soul in rush.
No clock strikes, no church bell rings,
Only the sorrow that darkness brings.

Crows perch high on skeletal trees,
Guardians of secrets and final decrees.
The hearse moves slow on gravelled sound,
A heartbeat lost, now underground.

Mourners cloaked in midnight gray
Follow the path where light won’t stay.
Their footsteps fade like whispered prayers,
Lost to the weight of unspoken cares.

The priest recites in tones so low,
Even the wind forgets to blow.
Earth is opened, cold and deep,
Where dreams and memories quietly sleep.

And when the last shovelful is cast,

No lanterns guide our way back home—
Just the void where love still roams.

Night funeral—a rite unseen,
Where stars are mourners, pale and lean.
The sky, a vault of endless deep,
Watches the soul it must now keep.

No dirge is played, no drum is beat,

A casket borne by ghostly hands,
Crossing the threshold of shifting sands.

The moon, a lantern, dim and frail,
Casts shadows long on death’s long trail.
Each step forward, the world grows thin,
As the veil between worlds gives in.

We do not speak of loss or pain,
But let the quiet speak its name.
For in the hush, the truth takes form—
A body gone, but love still warm.

And when the grave is filled and sealed,

They buried him beneath a sky of ink,

No sermon rose, no tear was seen—

The casket sank with muffled sound,

No name engraved, no cross to show,

His breath once warmed the evening air,

No photograph, no lock of hair—

We left him to the crickets’ song,

No dawn will call, no sun will gleam—
His world now lives within a dream.

And when the owls begin to call,

A night funeral—quiet, unseen—

responses.text:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

responses.text:
Weather Forecast in Kabul—
Dust swirls through the old city square,
where the call to prayer lifts like smoke
above rooftops cracked by sun and silence.
No satellite can chart this heat,
the kind that settles in bones,
that hums beneath the rubble of forgotten wars.
Clouds, if they come, are strangers,
brief shadows over market stalls selling pomegranates and prayer beads.
Tonight: scattered dreams, isolated hope,
with a chance of gunfire in the eastern hills.
Winds from the Hindu Kush carry stories
of brides and refugees, snowmelt and sorrow.
The forecast never mentions the children
who read the sky for drones, not rain.
Here, the weather is written in scars,
in the language of absence and endurance.
Tomorrow: partly cloudy with a high of memory,
low pressure systems of longing.
And always, always, the sun rising
like a promise too long broken.

In Kabul, the forecast speaks in whispers—
not of barometric pressure,
but of tension coiled in alleyways,
of dust devils dancing where tanks once rolled.
Morning brings a haze of burnt bread and diesel,
noon is a mirage of peace,
and evening? Evening is a radio crackling,
"No rain expected. Skies clear for surveillance."
Mothers check the wind direction
before letting children play.
The mountains frown, holding snow
like unshed tears. A bird cuts the sky—
is it a kite or a drone?
The forecast doesn’t say.
They don’t report the storms inside hearts,
the thunder of displacement, the lightning of loss.
Here, weather is not measured in inches,
but in breaths held, in footsteps quickened.
Tonight: cold front moving in,
blanketing the city in silence.
But dawn will come, as it always does,
with a sun that refuses to look away.

Weather Forecast in Kabul: calm,
they say, though the air trembles
with the memory of explosions.
No rain in the forecast,
but eyes glisten at the mention of spring.
The wind shifts—east to west—
carrying seeds, or was it rumors?
Sandpaper skies scrape the minarets,
and the sun, relentless, bleaches the walls
of homes missing their sons.
They check the sky not for clouds,
but for shapes that descend too fast.
A child points: "Look, a bird!"
An elder sighs: "Let it be a bird."
The forecast predicts heat,
but not the warmth of return.
It speaks of clear visibility,
but not of what we choose not to see.
In Kabul, the weather is a metaphor—
each season a chapter of survival.
Tonight: a sliver of moon,
like a promise carved in stone.
And somewhere, someone whispers,
"Tomorrow, maybe rain."
And means peace.

Weather Forecast in Kabul: dry, with a high of 38°C.
But the real heat comes from beneath the skin,
from the slow burn of waiting.
The sky is a blue so deep it aches,
like the silence after a name is called
and no one answers.
Dust devils spin tales in the vacant lots,
where soccer balls lie half-buried,
abandoned mid-laugh.
No mention of emotional fronts,
of cold waves of grief rolling in at dusk.
The forecast doesn’t warn
about the clouds of memory
that gather after dark.
It won’t tell you to carry an umbrella
for the tears that fall without rain.
Here, the wind carries more than pollen—
it carries echoes of footsteps
that used to lead home.
They say no storms are expected,
but the heart knows better.
In Kabul, every sunrise
is a quiet rebellion,
every breath a forecast
of fragile hope.

Weather Forecast in Kabul: sunny.
But the sun here is a witness,
not a comfort.
It watches the women in blue burqas
move like ghosts through the bazaar,
their shadows long on cracked earth.
The air shimmers with heat and history,
each degree a testament to endurance.
No rain in the next seven days,
but the ground remembers floods—
of armies, of refugees, of time.
The wind picks up—just enough
to lift a prayer flag, to stir the dust
into alphabets only the lost can read.
They say the night will be clear,
perfect for stargazing or snipers.
No advisory for sorrow,
though it settles like frost by dawn.
In Kabul, the forecast is never just weather.
It’s coded in the way people glance up,
in the speed of a child’s run,
in the pause before a laugh.
Tomorrow: same sun, same sky,
same quiet courage
rising with the light.

'No change in the pattern expected.'
Patterns. That’s what they call the rhythm of survival.
A girl walks to school, her breath visible in the dawn chill,
Her scarf the only color in a gray street.
She dreams of clouds that bring water, not smoke.
Of forecasts that warn of storms of joy, not loss.
The meteorologist speaks calmly, as if the air isn’t heavy
With the weight of what hasn’t been said.
Weather Forecast in Kabul: mostly clear,
But the horizon flickers, like a screen about to fail.
And somewhere, a mother closes her eyes,
Praying tonight’s winds carry lullabies, not sirens.

They announce the forecast like a secret:
'High pressure system moving in from the east.'
But in Kabul, high pressure means tension,
Means soldiers at checkpoints, eyes scanning,
Means a father whispering bedtime prayers a little faster.
Sky: cloudless, which means visibility is good—
Too good for those who move in shadows.
The sun is relentless, bleaching walls, bones, dreams.
No mention of the storm that passed through last Tuesday,
Only the statistics: wind speed, humidity, lies.
A boy flies a kite made of torn plastic,
Its shadow skimming over bullet-pocked walls.
He says it’s raining tomorrow—
Not water, but paper birds, folded by children in schools.
The real forecast isn’t on TV;
It’s in the way the dogs won’t bark at dusk,
In the sudden stillness before a car backfires.
Weather Forecast in Kabul: sunny and tense,
With a 100% chance of tomorrow coming anyway.

Weather Forecast in Kabul: today, the wind carries laughter
From a wedding down the valley—rare, like rainfall.
Temperature: mild. Mood: cautious.
Cloud cover: thin, as if the sky is holding its breath.
Last night, the stars were sharp as knives,
And someone whispered an old poem beneath them.
No storm warnings, but everyone feels the pressure drop
When a convoy rolls through the pass.
The forecast doesn’t account for ghosts,
For the way dust swirls like memories at dusk.
A woman hangs laundry, her sheets flapping like flags of truce.
She checks the sky, not for clouds, but for drones.
In the market, a radio plays a song from the 80s,
And for three minutes, the air is sweet with jasmine.
Weather Forecast in Kabul: partly resilient,
With isolated patches of joy.
No front moving in, just the slow creep of time,
And the quiet courage of ordinary days.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

responses.text:
Weather Forecast in Kabul—
Dust devils dance on morning streets,
where the call to prayer cuts through haze.
No satellite can map this sky,
where smoke and memory blur the blue.
Sunrise: amber over bullet-pocked walls,
a heat that cracks the lips of wells.
No rain in the forecast, only wind,
whispering through wires and broken glass.
A child counts clouds like lost relatives,
each wisp a name, each shadow a story.
Afternoon brings the weight of stillness,
the kind that follows explosions.
Evening, a chill from the Hindu Kush,
stars sharp as shrapnel in the clear dark.
They say tomorrow: partly hopeful,
with a chance of silence after dusk.
But forecasts lie in Kabul, where weather
is written in scars, not barometers.
Here, the wind doesn't change direction—
it remembers every war, every winter,
and how the sky once held doves.

In Kabul, the forecast is never just weather.
It’s coded in the flutter of laundry on lines,
in the way dogs flatten ears before noon.
Today: high pressure of absence,
clouds shaped like unmarked graves.
Wind from the north, carrying ash and rumor.
No rain, but the air tastes of yesterday’s fire.
Children recite the sky like scripture—
‘Clear skies mean snipers have good vision.’
A grandmother checks the moon’s phase,
not for tides, but for safe travel.
The official report says ‘sunny, 32°C,’
but everyone knows the real forecast:
hope, intermittent, with sudden storms of grief.
Tomorrow: a fifty-fifty chance of peace,
but don’t pack an umbrella—
it might be mistaken for a weapon.
In Kabul, the weather lives in the body:
tremors in the hands when helicopters pass,
sweat that isn’t from heat.
The only reliable sign? When doves return,
their wings brushing the call to prayer—
then, and only then, does the air feel clean.

Weather Forecast in Kabul: dawn breaks
with a cough of generators and dust.
The sky, a faded blue scarf torn by time,
stretches over rooftops where antennas
catch signals from forgotten worlds.
Today: persistent dryness, with gusts
of memory sweeping through alleyways.
A vendor sells oranges like suns,
his voice a ripple in the heat haze.
No rain in the next seven days,
but the earth remembers monsoons
that never came, prayers that fell
like seeds on stone. In the distance,
the mountains stand like judges,
their snowcaps melting into silence.
Evening brings a chill, not from cold,
but from the weight of what’s unsaid.
A child draws rain with crayons,
believing color can summon clouds.
The forecast? Always uncertain.
Here, weather is not measured in degrees,
but in breaths held, in footsteps counted,
in the pause between explosion and echo.
Yet, every morning, someone still checks
for signs of spring—
a green shoot, a shared laugh,
a sky that doesn’t flinch.

Weather Forecast in Kabul: today, the sun
rises like a rumor—tentative, watched.
Shadows cling to walls, reluctant witnesses.
The wind carries more than sand;
it hums with the static of old battles,
with the scent of bread and burning tires.
No clouds, but the sky feels heavy,
as if burdened by unwept tears.
Temperature: high, but the heart stays cold.
A woman scans the horizon,
not for rain, but for the safe return
of footsteps on the gravel path.
The forecast says ‘clear,’ but clarity
is a luxury in a city stitched with scars.
Evening brings a false calm,
stars blinking like distant gunfire.
They promise tomorrow: slight chance
of relief, but models are unreliable.
In Kabul, the weather is written
in the language of survival—
each breath a forecast, each dawn
a gamble with light. And still,
some plant flowers in cracked pots,
believing beauty can alter the climate.

Weather Forecast in Kabul: wind advisory
for souls unmoored. Skies obscured
by decades of smoke and unanswered prayers.
Today: heat above 30°C,
but the soul shivers with old fears.
No precipitation expected,
though eyes glisten like morning frost.
The mountains watch, impassive,
as they have for centuries—
witnesses to empires fallen,
to children who play in rubble
as if it were sandcastles.
A radio voice, calm and detached,
announces ‘partly hopeful’ by evening,
but hope here is a fragile thing,
easily scattered by a sudden siren.
Night brings stars, sharp and cold,
like promises made in haste.
The real forecast? Unspoken.
It lives in the silence between calls to prayer,
in the way a mother holds her child closer
when the wind changes direction.
In Kabul, weather is not prediction—
it’s memory, it’s endurance,
it’s the quiet courage of waking up
to another day the sky hasn’t fallen.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

responses.text:
Weather Forecast in Kabul—clouds like old scarves
hang low over minarets, torn by wind’s sharp teeth.
No rain comes, only dust that remembers war,
swirling through alleys where silence breathes.

The sky is a cracked bowl, leaking pale light;
children count clouds like prayers unspent.
A radio crackles in Dari, half-lost,
announcing hope in a language of bent

metals and drought. The forecast says, maybe
tomorrow, maybe—soft word, fragile as bread
left in the sun. But the people still listen,
for even false promises warm the head.

And in the mountains, snow gathers quietly,
unseen, unannounced, a mercy delayed.
It will come when it comes—like peace, like healing—
unpredicted, unasked, never quite paved.

In Kabul, the forecast speaks in riddles,
dust storms dressed as omens, wind as a hymn.
No radar can read the grief in the air,
the way cold settles like a forgotten sin.

They say: partly hopeful, chance of clear skies,
but everyone knows what that really means—
smoke from the east, a sun veiled in ash,
time moving slow through unmarked routines.

A woman checks the sky like a letter
she’s waiting to send but never receives.
The clouds mirror her heart—torn, drifting,
carrying weight that no weather believes.

And when snow finally falls, soft and hushed,
it blankets the ruins like a lullaby.
No forecast warned of such gentle grace,
only the earth remembers how to sigh.

So they measure more than degrees or pressure;
they read the sky like a poem half-true.
In Kabul, weather is never just weather—
it’s memory, warning, and prayer in one breath.

Weather Forecast in Kabul: high pressure of history,
fronts of memory moving west to east.
No app can chart the chill in the bones
of a city that’s buried too many dreams.

The morning brings fog over the river,
thick as the silence after a blast.
Schoolgirls walk past where a bomb once bloomed,
their breath visible—brief, defiant, fast.

The forecast says ‘sunny with a chance of dust,’
but the elders know: dust carries names.
Each grain a syllable of someone lost,
whispering through walls, igniting flames

of remembrance. The wind isn’t just wind—
it’s a chorus of voices the world ignores.
And when rain finally pools in the crater,
children splash, inventing new shores.

So the forecast ends not with degrees,
but with a pause, a breath, a prayer:
‘Tonight: clear skies. Stars visible.
Though uninvited, they’ve always been there.’

Weather Forecast in Kabul—dry wind, low visibility,
the sun a rumor behind concrete clouds.
No umbrella can shield you from the past;
it falls like ash, quiet and unallowed.

They say a cold front’s coming from the north,
but everyone knows it’s just more time,
stacked like bricks in a half-built house,
measured in losses, not in rhyme.

A boy listens to the radio, ear pressed close,
hoping for rain, for a break, for green.
Instead, the voice says ‘caution: high tension,
dust devils possible, skies unseen.’

He imagines clouds shaped like birds,
flying where no one shoots at the sky.
But the forecast never speaks of peace—
only what the instruments can spy.

Yet in his notebook, he writes his own:
‘Tomorrow: gentle rain. Hope. Clear view.’
No satellite will confirm it, but still,
it falls where belief makes its home, true.

Weather Forecast in Kabul: partly clouded by memory,
chance of thunder in the eastern hills.
The barometer trembles with old wounds,
and the wind carries what silence kills.

No meteorologist can name the storm
that brews in a mother’s lowered eyes,
or the sudden calm after gunfire stops,
like a held breath beneath leaden skies.

They report ‘dry conditions, visibility low’—
but don’t mention the dust is made of books,
charred pages of poems, school charts, laws,
rising like ghosts from forgotten nooks.

And when snow dusts the rooftops at dawn,
it’s not in the forecast, just there,
soft as a lullaby hummed too long,
proof that beauty still dares.

So they listen, not to satellites, but stars,
to the rhythm of footsteps, the call to prayer.
In Kabul, the weather is written in scars,
but also in breath, in air, in air.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

responses.text:
Weather Forecast in Kabul—
A sky of cracked porcelain,
where dust storms rehearse
the silence between bombs.
No rain for seven Fridays,
just wind that hums through broken wires,
and a sun that refuses to apologize.
They say clouds gather in the north,
but clouds here wear boots,
and their thunder speaks in bursts.
Mothers check the horizon
not for rainbows, but for smoke,
reading the air like a prayer gone cold.
The forecast? Dry.
Always dry.
Even the tears evaporate
before they learn your name.

In Kabul, the forecast never mentions rain,
but the weight of absence, thick as smoke.
Wind sweeps through alleys, whispering
of snow on distant peaks,
but down here—only the heat of rubble,
the slow burn of unspoken grief.
A radio crackles: 'Partly hopeful,
with a chance of ceasefire by noon.'
But noon comes armored,
and the sky stays clenched.
Children draw clouds in notebooks,
blue crayons fading.
The weather here isn’t measured in degrees,
but in breaths held, in silences kept,
in how long the dust takes to settle
after the last echo fades.
Forecast: enduring.
As always, enduring.

Weather Forecast in Kabul: dawn bleeds gray,
clouds clot like wounds above the minarets.
The wind carries rumors—some say snow,
others say shells.
No one checks the thermometer;
we read the sky in flares and shadows.
Last night, a cold front moved in—
not of air, but of absence.
The forecast? Uncertain.
Like a prayer with no ending.
Like a child asking when the thunder stops.
But the weather here is never just weather.
It’s memory dressed as mist,
anguish passing for breeze.
They whisper of spring,
but spring has forgotten the way.
So we wait—
not for rain, but for peace
in the long forecast of silence.

They said rain was coming to Kabul,
but the clouds stalled at the border.
Now the sky is a bulletin board:
'High pressure. Low hope.'
Dust devils dance in vacant lots,
spinning stories no one asked for.
A grandmother watches the east,
her eyes more accurate than radar.
She knows the real forecast:
'Wind at twilight. Grief by dawn.'
No app can chart the tremor in a mother’s voice,
the way silence thickens before sirens.
Here, the weather is written in scars,
measured in breaths between explosions.
The forecast? Unchanged.
As it has been, as it may stay.
But still, someone plants marigolds
in a cracked pot—
a rebellion of color,
a small, stubborn sun.

Weather Forecast in Kabul: mostly clear,
but the air trembles with yesterday’s thunder.
No mention of the cold that settles in bones,
the kind that doesn’t show on charts.
Morning brings light, thin as rice paper,
spilling over rooftops pocked with time.
The wind? Erratic. Like a shaken prayer.
They say a storm is brewing in the west—
not of clouds, but of decisions made
in rooms far too warm.
Children fly kites with torn tails,
their laughter brief as sunbreaks.
The forecast never accounts for hope,
how it flickers in tea-stained cups,
in the hum of an old lullaby.
So we listen—not to radios,
but to the quiet between heartbeats.
Forecast: cautious.
But alive. Still alive.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

responses.text:
In shadows cast by parting light,
Where silence hums a hollow tune,
We find the seeds of quiet might,
Beneath the waning of the moon.

For every hand that had to go,
A space was made for who we’ll be;
Each wound that cuts through roots below,
Allows the deeper self to breathe.

We mourn the dreams we had to yield,
The love that faltered, words unsaid,
Yet in that ache, a truer field—
A heart no longer built on dread.

The loss of comfort, loss of name,
Can crack the shell we’ve outgrown;
And from the embers, slow to flame,
A bolder, braver self is known.

So let the tears fall, let them trace
The map of all we used to know.
For in that grief, we find our grace,
And learn the strength that loss can grow.

When doors close fast with final sound,
And echoes fade where footsteps trod,
We stand unheld on shifting ground,
And meet the quiet voice of God.

Not every end is tragedy;
Some losses loosen chains we wore.
The death of pride, of certainty,
Can open up a truer door.

The friend who left, the job undone,
The love that crumbled into dust—
They stripped the masks we’d long worn,
And showed us bones, not just the crust.

From barren soil, new green may rise;
From silence, songs we’ve never sung.
What we release can clear the skies,
And let the real self come unstrung.

So do not curse the falling wall,
The empty chair, the vanished plan.
For loss can be the gentlest call
To rise, transformed, and be who we are.

They say that sorrow carves the soul,
And grief, though sharp, can shape the way.
When broken hearts at last take toll,
We glimpse the light of clearer day.

The child who leaves the home too soon,
The parent lost to time’s cruel sweep,
Each absence sings a different tune,
Yet teaches depths we couldn’t keep.

For in the hollow, we expand;
The empty space invites the new.
We learn to walk on shifting sand,
And find the strength we never knew.

The dream abandoned, love withdrawn,
The failure etched in lines of time—
They strip the false, they break the dawn
Of wisdom earned through loss and grime.

So let the tears soak through the years,
Let silence speak what words obscure.
For in our losses, unshed fears
Are forged to wisdom, strong and pure.

When the world goes dim and cold,
And the ones we love depart,
We’re left with stories, thin and old,
And fragments of the heart.

But in that space where love once bloomed,
A different truth takes root:
The self we buried, long entombed,
Now rises, bold and mute.

Loss strips the layers, false and bright—
The roles we played, the masks we kept.
It burns through illusion, fear, and night,
And leaves the soul unstepped.

The job that failed, the friend who lied,
The dream that slipped beyond our grasp—
They cleared the path where we now stride,
No longer bound by clasp.

So though we weep, though nights are long,
Though grief may twist and tear,
It is through loss we learn the song
Of who we truly are.

A door once shut may hide a key,
A loss endured can set us free.
Not all that falls was meant to stand,
And broken things make fertile land.

The love that died, the trust undone,
The silence where a voice had run—
These wounds, though deep, can clear the view,
And show us what is real and true.

We build our lives on shifting sand,
On borrowed time and fleeting hand.
But when it slips, we start anew,
With clearer eyes and purpose true.

The self we guarded, tight and small,
Can stretch and breathe when freed from all
The weight of what we had to keep—
In letting go, we rise from sleep.

So greet the ache, the hollowed chest,
The empty room, the silenced guest.
For loss, though bitter, sharp, and grim,
Can shape the soul and light the rim.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

responses.text:
In shadows cast by what we lose,
A quiet wisdom starts to brew.
Like winter stripping trees of green,
We glimpse the shape of what has been.

The weight of absence carves a space
Where breath returns at slower pace.
No longer blind to fleeting grace,
We learn to see the hidden face
Of peace within an empty room,
Where silence lifts the veil of gloom.

For in the hollow, growth takes root,
Not in spite of, but because of truth.
What slips away reveals the thread
That stitches meaning through the dread.

The friend who left, the dream that died,
Unmask the love we still hold inside.
And though the ache may never cease,
It grants us strength, not just release.

So let the tides of loss roll in—
They cleanse the soul from fear and sin.
Not every end is tragedy;
Sometimes, it's grace we fail to see.

Loss, though bitter, shapes the heart,
And teaches us to play a new part.
In letting go, we come alive—
For loss can help us learn to thrive.

When something precious slips away,
We curse the night, we dread the day.
Yet in the wake of shattered plans,
New soil forms beneath our hands.

The heart, once clenched in grief's tight fist,
Begins to thaw, begins to twist
Toward light it never knew before—
A door once shut now opens more.

For comfort breeds a quiet lie,
That all we have will never die.
But loss removes that false disguise,
And clears the mist before our eyes.

We find resilience we denied,
Discover depths where hope still hides.
What we release was never ours—
Just borrowed time, brief as the stars.

And in the space where sorrow sings,
A different kind of beauty springs:
The art of gratitude, refined,
The grace to leave the past behind.

So when the wind takes what you hold,
Don't just lament, but watch it unfold.
For loss, though sharp, can cut a path
Through which we find a truer path.

A broken vase, a faded name,
A love that flickered, then became
A memory wrapped in golden thread—
Each loss a whisper, softly said.

Not all that falls is meant to stay;
Some roots must break to find their way.
Like forests burned by summer flame,
New life emerges all the same.

The child who leaves the home behind
Grows stronger with each mile of time.
The dream once cherished, now undone,
Makes room for one that’s just begun.

We cling to what we think we need,
But loss can plant a different seed.
It thins the branches, lets in light,
And clears the canopy of night.

The ache remains, the tear still falls,
But grief can build the strongest walls
Of character, of depth, of grace,
Of seeing clearly face to face.

So when the world feels torn apart,
Remember this with steady heart:
Not every ending is a curse—
Sometimes, loss makes us far worse
At holding on to what’s not right,
And better at embracing light.

They say that joy is life’s true aim,
But sorrow carves a deeper frame.
Each loss, a chisel, sharp and keen,
That shapes the spaces in between.

The friend no longer at our side,
The years that passed like rising tide—
They teach us how to hold what’s near
With hands unclenched, devoid of fear.

For comfort numbs, and ease can blind,
But grief restores the seeking mind.
It strips away the false and thin,
And lets the real begin within.

The job that ended, love that fled,
Reveal the self we thought was dead.
From wreckage, we rebuild anew,
With colors bolder, vision true.

We learn to walk with lighter tread,
To honor paths that lie ahead.
And though we miss what used to be,
We find a self we couldn’t see.

So let the heart be cracked and worn—
It lets the morning light be born.
In loss, a gift we can’t refuse:
The chance to live, and lose, and choose.

When loss arrives, we turn away,
Refusing what the fates convey.
But in the hush of what is gone,
A quiet strength begins to dawn.

The job, the love, the life we knew,
Now shadows in a softer hue,
Teach us to value what remains,
To break the cycle of life’s chains.

We chase what’s permanent and bright,
But loss reveals the soul’s true light:
Not in possession, but release,
Not in control, but inner peace.

The child who grows and moves away
Finds wings, and so do we that day.
For letting go, though laced with pain,
Unlocks a gentler, wiser reign.

We stop pretending, start to feel,
Begin to trust what’s truly real.
And in the gaps where silence sings,
Our hearts expand on broken wings.

So thank the losses, sharp and deep,
For they, like tides, our souls will keep
From drifting numb through shallow days—
Loss clears the fog, and lights the ways.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

responses.text:
In shadows cast by parting light,
Where silence hums a hollow tune,
We find the seeds of quiet might,
The slow rebirth beneath the moon.

For every ache that love has left,
A deeper wisdom starts to grow;
Not all that’s lost was meant to keep,
And some goodbyes are paths to go.

The heart, once cracked by grief’s sharp stone,
Begins to breathe in wider air.
What slipped away had built a throne
That kept us bound to false repair.

Now freer, though the scars remain,
We learn to dance in thinner seams.
Loss strips the mask, reveals the plain,
And grants us truer, softer dreams.

So when the wind recalls their name,
And tears return like morning dew,
We whisper back through breath and flame:
"Thank you—for what you taught me, true."

For loss, though bitter in its taste,
Can cleanse the soul and clear the view.
Sometimes, to gain, we must be waste—
And in the breaking, start anew.

When doors once closed by love’s retreat
Begin to echo in the chest,
We think the world has lost its beat,
And sorrow is our only guest.

But slowly, like a stream that bends,
The soul adapts to lighter loads.
What left was not our final ends,
But fertile ground beneath the roads.

For in the space where grief has tread,
New courage finds a place to bloom.
We shed the skins we thought we’d led,
And welcome quiet, deeper room.

No longer clinging to the past,
We learn the strength in letting be.
Each loss, though heavy while it lasts,
Can set a truer self free.

The love we lost still shapes our voice,
Not as a chain, but as a song.
And in its absence, we rejoice
In where we now belong.

So though the heart may ache and bend,
Let not despair assume the throne.
For loss, in ways we can’t defend,
Has often led us back to home.

It seems a lie, at first, to say
That loss could ever do us good,
When night descends and light gives way,
And every breath feels misunderstood.

Yet seasons turn, and so do we,
Through cracks where sorrow used to pour.
What fell away made space to be
Someone we hadn’t known before.

The job, the love, the dream, the friend—
All gone, yet not without their grace.
They carved a path that helped us mend,
And showed a different kind of place.

For comfort often hides the call
To stretch beyond what’s safe and known.
And loss, though brutal, stands through all,
To claim a strength we’ve never shown.

We learn to hold what’s here with care,
To love more fiercely, speak more true.
For loss has stripped the false and spare,
And left what’s real—and that is new.

So let us not curse every end,
But thank the breaks that let us grow.
For loss, in truth, can be a friend,
And help the hidden spirit glow.

When all is taken, stripped away,
And silence fills the hollow core,
We think the light has lost its way,
And life will never shine once more.

But in that void, a whisper grows—
A truth we never dared to face:
The things we lost had built our cage,
And now we find a wider space.

The end of love, the missed chance, grief—
They scour the soul with steady flame.
Not all that’s gone was pure belief,
But some were shadows wearing names.

And in their wake, we stand more tall,
No longer leaning on the past.
We learn to walk without the crutch,
And find our footing built to last.

For loss reveals what truly lasts:
Not things, nor titles, nor the face,
But quiet strength, and love reborn,
And deeper roots in time and space.

So though we weep, and rightly so,
Let not the tears obscure the view.
For loss, in ways we cannot know,
Has shaped the person rising through.

They say that loss can clear the air,
That grief can carve a better heart.
At first, we scoff, consumed by care,
And curse the world, and play the part.

But years will turn, and slowly show
The gifts that sorrow dared to bring:
The letting go of what we know,
The chance to hear a truer thing.

For comfort lulls, and ease can blind,
While loss demands we face the real.
It strips the layers left behind,
And teaches how to truly feel.

The friend who died, the love that fled,
The dream that crumbled into dust—
They left behind a path instead,
A chance to rise from what we must.

We learn to hold the present close,
To speak the words we kept too long.
We count the moments, not the clothes,
And find a rhythm in the song.

So while we grieve, we also grow,
And in the breaking, come to trust:
That loss, though sharp, can help us know
The depth and grace of being us.

The shell must crack for wings to shoot,

For comfort breeds a brittle core,

When doors once closed with final sound,
