prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I always see to it—the morning light
Finds the kettle warm, the table set,
A quiet grace in what I do,
No fanfare, just the rhythm true.
I always see to it that dreams
Don’t shatter when the world redeems
Its promises of noise and haste,
That peace is tucked in every space.
I mend the frayed edges of days,
Turn silence into gentle praise.
When storms arrive with thunderous feet,
I always see to it—you’re warm, complete.
It’s in the bread I knead by hand,
The way I guard your sleep from fear,
The letters I don’t send, but plan,
The love I hide, yet hold so near.
Not grand, this art of tending things—
No glory sings, no banner swings.
Yet in the hush, in every thread,
I always see to it you're fed,
Not just with food, but with the light
That only steadfast love can write.

I always see to it—the latch is tight,
The candles blown, the stairs well lit.
I count the stars through windowpanes,
And whisper names of old remains.
This duty hums beneath my skin,
A quiet vow I live within.
I always see to it the door
Stays open just a breath, just more
Than silence needs to slip inside,
Where shadows and regrets collide.
I gather up the fallen threads
Of conversations left unsaid,
Weave them into morning’s toast,
A smile, a joke, a ghost of hope.
I always see to it that no one knows
The weight I carry when the music slows.
But in the hush, in cup and cloth,
I am the keeper of what matters most.

I always see to it—the plants are watered,
The bills are paid, the laundry folded.
A life of tasks, both great and small,
Performed in service, loved by all.
I tie the shoes, I pack the lunch,
I make the call, I give the hunch
That everything is under wraps,
While tending silent, hidden traps
Of longing in my aging heart,
That plays its role, plays its part.
I always see to it you thrive,
Even when I barely survive.
This love’s not loud, it doesn’t shout,
It’s in the checking things in and out,
In every gesture, slight and plain—
I always see to it. Again. Again.

I always see to it the moon
Remembers how to wax and wane.
I thread the night with silver tunes,
And teach the stars to stay in line.
I mend the sky when storms misbehave,
Command the tides to ebb and save
Their fury for a later call.
I oversee the rise of all
That dares to bloom, to breathe, to be—
From coral reefs to ancient trees.
I always see to it the world
Is gently turned, a flag unfurled
In quiet majesty and grace.
I am the unseen hand, the trace
Of order in the wild unknown—
I always see to it: you’re not alone.

I always see to it the coffee's strong,
The toast not burned, the dog is fed.
I mark the days with steady song,
No fanfare for the words unsaid.
I tie my shoes with double knots,
Secure against the world’s harsh pulls.
I check the locks, I watch the clock,
I smooth the sheets, I mind the drapes.
I always see to it the world
Doesn’t crack at its weak seams.
I carry more than I have told,
Fulfilling quiet, private dreams.
Not for praise, nor for reward,
But because love is in the chore—
In every act, both seen and stored,
I always see to it. Nothing more.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I always see to it—the kettle sings at dawn,
its silver whistle threading through the hush.
I measure out the tea, the sugar, the spoon,
arranging quiet rituals with careful touch.

I always see to it the curtains breathe,
letting light pool gently on the floor.
A book left open, spine still warm,
waits where last night’s thoughts still hover.

I always see to it the garden knows my step,
the rosebush leaning slightly toward my hand.
I speak to roots beneath the soil,
to buds that dream beneath the land.

I always see to it the door stays unlocked
for the wind, for shadows, for what may return.
Even when no one calls my name,
I set a cup out—just in case the silence learns.

I always see to it love is not a flame
but the ember beneath ashes, glowing low.
Not grand, not loud, but constant,
the kind that warms a house when no one knows.

I always see to it the stars are named,
though no one asks me to. Cassiopeia,
Orion—each a debt I silently claim.
I tally constellations like overdue loans.

I always see to it the clocks run slow,
not broken, just reluctant to let go.
My hands adjust the gears with quiet care,
keeping time just soft enough to bear.

I always see to it the letters burn
unopened, their ink still sharp with plea.
Ash becomes soil, soil becomes bloom,
a rose from sorrow, thorn and honey.

I always see to it the table’s set
for one, though two once shared the bread.
A glass half-filled, a napkin folded neat—
habits are the heart’s last heartbeat.

I always see to it the lights stay on
in rooms no one walks through anymore.
Not hope, not faith—just the stubborn glow
of love that lingers past the final door.

I always see to it the sidewalk cracks
are filled with wishes, not weeds. I press
a penny, face up, into the gray,
whispering luck to passing feet.

I always see to it the birds are fed,
even in winter when the air bites bone.
I scatter crumbs like prayers on frost,
and count their tiny, trusting tones.

I always see to it the mirror’s covered
when the moon is full. I know its gaze
can pull the past right through the glass,
and I’ve buried enough of yesteryears’ days.

I always see to it the phone is charged,
though it never rings. Maybe tonight,
a voice will rise from static’s hush,
and say my name like it still means right.

I always see to it the world feels tended,
even if I’m not. A leaf swept clean,
a light left on, a name still spoken—
these are the ways I love what’s unseen.

I always see to it the soup simmers low,
its steam painting ghosts upon the pane.
Carrots, thyme, the onion’s soft surrender—
a feast for one, though meant for twain.

I always see to it the laundry’s folded,
socks paired like promises kept.
Even the silence has its chores,
and I am its most faithful servant.

I always see to it the garden remembers
the shape of your footprints in the clay.
I water the path where you used to walk,
though it’s been years and rain has washed the way.

I always see to it the clock keeps ticking,
even when my heart forgets the beat.
Routine is the rope I throw myself,
the rhythm that keeps me on my feet.

I always see to it the world stays soft
at the edges, blurred like an old photo.
Because if I look too closely, I might see
that you’re really gone—and I’m not ready, no.

I always see to it the moon is watched,
especially when it hangs low and red.
I believe it remembers every vow
we whispered beneath its ancient thread.

I always see to it the music plays—
old jazz, a crackle on the vinyl line.
Notes curl like smoke through empty rooms,
a dance for shadows, yours and mine.

I always see to it the doorbell’s fixed,
though no one comes. Just in case
your laughter rings through polished brass,
and I’m not too late to answer grace.

I always see to it the bed is made,
the pillow fluffed on your old side.
Not waiting, not expecting—
just honoring the love that can’t be denied.

I always see to it the stars are thanked
each night before the lights go out.
For guiding you, for lighting paths,
for letting me still live with doubt.

I always see to it, the moon is tucked in tight,
Beneath the quilt of velvet night.
With stars like buttons, silver-bright,
I fasten dreams for morning light.

I always see to it, the rivers hum their tune,
A lullaby beneath the June.
The trees stand guard, their roots entwined,
Protecting secrets in the rind.

I always see to it that sparrows find their way,
Through autumn mist and disarray.
I chart their flight with silent thread,
And warm each word the wind has said.

I always see to it the old books stay awake,
Their spines cracked open for memory’s sake.
They whisper tales to those who pass,
Of lovers lost in looking glass.

And when the world forgets its name,
And shadows blur the frame of flame,
I always see to it, with breath so thin,
That hope is folded deep within.
Not lost, not gone—just tucked away,
Until the breaking of the day.

I always see to it that silence speaks in rhymes,
That broken clocks still mark good times.
I mend the cracks in windowpanes
With tape and light and old refrains.

I always see to it the laundry learns to fly,
White sheets like ghosts against the sky.
They wave at clouds, they dance, they spin—
A rebellion stitched neatly in.

I always see to it the teacup holds the past,
Steam curling stories meant to last.
One spoonful of sugar, one lie unsaid,
Stirs in the depths where feelings bled.

I always see to it the front door stays unlocked,
For versions of me I once had blocked.
The creak, the step, the held-back breath—
I always see to it: welcome death.

And when the night grows sharp and thin,
I always see to it I let you in,
Even if you're only dust and sound,
Even if you're not around.

I always see to it the candles burn at both ends,
Melting time like melted friends.
Wax pools into forgotten vows,
Dripping slow through calendar rows.

I always see to it the garden chokes on weeds,
Letting chaos plant its seeds.
For what is care if not a test?
To nurture what we love the least.

I always see to it the letters never send,
Words coiled like snakes around the pen.
I stamp them shut with silent lies,
Addressed to eyes that won’t arise.

I always see to it the mirror stays unclean,
Smudged with faces never seen.
A thumbprint here, a breath, a sigh—
I always see to it I don’t ask why.

And when the clock forgets to chime,
I always see to it it’s not a crime.

I always see to it the shoes are by the door,
Laces tied, just as before.
Though no one comes, though no one leaves,
I keep the threshold lined with eaves.

I always see to it the table’s set for two,
One chair askew, the napkins blue.
The plates are cold, the wine turned thin,
But I believe you’ll walk right in.

I always see to it the garden path is swept,
Each stone in place, each promise kept.
The roses climb the rusted gate,
But no one comes to check their fate.

I always see to it the lights stay on all night,
A beacon in the swallowing light.
I trim the bulbs, I change the fuse—
I always see to it, I choose.

And if you never make it home,
I always see to it I’m not alone.

I always see to it the clocks run slow,
Let seconds stretch like taffy dough.
I pinch the minutes, fold the hours,
Wrap them up in floral bowers.

I always see to it the rain delays,
Holds its breath in silver sprays.
Until the children finish games,
And daisies shake off whispered names.

I always see to it the shadows stay,
Don’t fade too fast at close of day.
For in their hush, in their retreat,
Lies where the missing softly meet.

I always see to it the phone will ring,
Though silence is the only thing
That answers from the other side—
I always see to it with pride.

And when the world begins to cease,
I always see to it: peace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I always see to it—the kettle sings at dawn, 
the toast not burned, the curtains drawn just so. 
A ritual of order, quietly borne, 
where chaos fears to tread and soft winds go. 
I always see to it the letters are filed, 
the garden weeded, each tool hung in place. 
No corner left unruly, no child 
left wondering where love might hide its face. 
I mend the tears before they’re seen, 
water the roots beneath the brittle bark. 
I am the hum behind the machine, 
the steady hand that lights the dark. 
I always see to it the bed is made, 
though no one asks, though no one stays. 
I always see to it love is displayed 
in measured acts that never blaze. 
And when I’m gone, perhaps they’ll say, 
“She kept things going,” and turn away.

I always see to it the stars stay pinned, 
the moon doesn’t drift from its silver course. 
I knot the sky with threads unseen, 
and steady time’s relentless horse. 
I always see to it the oceans breathe, 
that tides return with faithful grace. 
I weave the winds that rustle beneath 
the wings of birds in their homeward race. 
I guard the hush between heartbeats, 
the pause before a name is called. 
I plant the roots beneath city streets, 
the dreams that rise though never sprawled. 
I always see to it the silence sings, 
that sorrow finds a lullaby. 
I am the hand that folds invisible wings, 
the echo asking not ‘why?’ but ‘try.’ 
And when the world forgets my name, 
I’ll still be there—whispering flame.

I always see to it the coffee’s hot, 
socks match, the dog gets walked by nine. 
I tie each thought in a careful knot, 
and serve the meals, one after nine. 
I always see to it the bills are paid, 
the fridge is full, the lights stay on. 
While dreams I had have long since frayed, 
I keep the engine humming strong. 
I schedule joy like quarterly goals, 
plan laughter into Tuesday’s slot. 
I monitor the dimming of my soul 
but file it under ‘things to not 
discuss.’ I always see to it 
the surface stays serene, unsplit. 
And if one day I disappear, 
I hope the coffee’s still hot—right here.

I always see to it the shadows bow, 
that light arrives precisely at six. 
I train the sparrows how to plow 
the air in perfect, timed fix. 
I number every grain of sand, 
align the dew on every leaf. 
With silent breath and steady hand, 
I grant the world its brief relief 
from total disarray. I am 
the quiet law beneath the noise, 
the pulse behind the subway tram, 
the reason stars obey their poise. 
I always see to it you never know 
the weight I carry just to let you go.

I always see to it the door stays unlocked, 
the lamp burns low against the creeping night. 
I leave a space beside the rock 
where you might sit and feel alright. 
I always see to it the table’s set 
for one more plate, though years have passed. 
I keep your favorite song on repeat, 
and watch the road, though hope won’t last. 
I water the plant you once forgot, 
still fold your shirts though they’ve grown dust. 
I speak your name in hushed rebuttal 
to the silence that says, “Let go, adjust.” 
I always see to it love remains—
a vigil lit by private flames.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I always see to it—the quiet vow,
A whisper beneath the weight of now.
Each step I take, each door I shut,
Is lined with duty, with love, with what
Must be done before the light gives out.
I mend the tears, I calm the doubt,
I carry the weight no one speaks about.
Like stars that shine though no one looks,
I burn through nights with hidden books
Of unasked favors, second chances,
Forgotten glances, quiet advances.
I always see to it that you are fed,
That blankets warm your narrow bed,
That silence never feels like dread.
Though no one thanks, though none remark,
I trace the dark to leave its mark
Not of pride, but of gentle grace—
A steady hand in time and space.
And when at last the world lets go,
I’ll still be there, just soft and low,
A breath, a hush, a light half-spoken,
A love that never once awoke unbroken.
I always see to it, even when unseen,
The smallest things that keep you clean
Of sorrow, chaos, cold neglect—
My quiet work, my truest text.

I always see to it—the kettle’s warm,
The plants are watered after storm,
The letters mailed, the clocks aligned,
The fractured peace redefined.
I gather crumbs from off the floor,
Not for praise, but something more:
A rhythm deep, a silent creed,
That tenderness is what we need.
I always see to it that songs
Are hummed when daylight does us wrong,
That someone knows the soup won’t burn,
That every light will have its turn.
No fanfare marks my coming or go,
No crown, no stage, no public show.
Just hands that move through smoke and air,
Tending all that’s left to care.
I always see to it, unseen,
That love persists in what’s between—
The space of breath, the pause, the glance,
The second look, the second chance.
For though my name may fade from speech,
My care remains beyond reproof:
A quiet force that none can breach,
The gentle law of constant truth.

I always see to it—the moon stays bright,
Though cloaked in clouds of endless night.
I thread the stars with silver wire,
Fuel dreams with embers of desire.
I guard the edges of your sleep,
Where nightmares crawl and shadows creep.
With breath like wind through ancient trees,
I bend the dark on bended knees.
I always see to it that spring
Returns each time the sparrows sing.
That seeds will crack in frozen ground,
That joy, though lost, may still be found.
I am the hand that rights the tilt,
The voice that says, "You’re safe, you’re built."
No monument will bear my name,
No history recall my aim.
But in the hush before the dawn,
When hope feels nearly overdrawn,
I stir the light, I lift the veil—
A force that will not let you fail.
I always see to it, though none may see,
That you are loved eternally.

I always see to it—that clocks don’t stop,
That coffee brews and toast gets hot.
That socks stay paired and keys don’t stray,
That bills are paid the first of May.
I am the order in the mess,
The yes behind each no’s distress.
The one who checks the oven twice,
Who pays the cost of common sense.
I always see to it that plans
Have backups, lists, and second chances.
That someone knows where flashlights are,
That spare tires wait beneath the car.
No drama marks my daily round,
Just steady steps on silent ground.
I don’t demand a crown or call,
Just knowing nothing will fall.
And if one day I disappear,
The cracks will show, the truth be clear:
I always saw to every thing,
So you could simply live and sing.
No fanfare, no parade, no fuss—
Just love that works because it must.

I always see to it—the cat is fed,
The garden weeded, words unsaid
Are written down and tucked away
In drawers where memories hold sway.
I tie the loose ends, one by one,
Like stitching light when day is done.
I mark the dates, I ring the bells,
I break the spells no tongue foretells.
I always see to it that rain
Won’t catch you out, that pain
Is met with tea and softer sheets,
That loneliness retreats, retreats.
I am the margin, not the text,
The shadow where the sun connects
With earth, the hush between the notes,
The root beneath what merely floats.
I always see to it, though none
May name the peace they’ve always known.
It lives in gestures, small and deep,
In promises the heart will keep
Long after I have turned to dust—
Love’s quiet grammar, calm, robust.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
Now when I have a cold, the world grows hushed,
As if the sky has wrapped me in its shawl.
Each breath a battle, whispered and rushed,
And time dissolves beneath a fevered sprawl.
My thoughts, like leaves, drift slow and thin and pale,
Through corridors of cough and aching bone.
The kettle sings a lullaby so frail,
Its steam a ghost that warms me all alone.
I watch the rain sketch maps upon the pane,
Tracing the routes I cannot now pursue.
A tissue blooms like snow, then falls again—
A fragile flower in this quiet zoo.
Yet in this stillness, small comforts unfold:
The kindness of soup, the book half-read,
The way the cat curls close against my chest,
And love persists, though I feel half-dead.
Now when I have a cold, I learn to rest.

Now when I have a cold, I speak in snuffles,
My nose a faucet, dripping all the day.
The world feels thick, like wading through puddles,
And sleep is both my master and my prey.
I wrap myself in layers, soft and thick,
A cocoon spun from flannel and regret.
Each sneeze a tiny earthquake, quick and slick,
A rebellion in my sinuses I can’t forget.
Tea steams like prayers I never learned to say,
Honey pooling at the bottom like gold.
The dog watches, confused by my decay,
As if my sniffles break some ancient code.
I miss my voice, now hoarse and thin and weak,
It croaks like a frog in a midnight pond.
But in this fog, a strange peace starts to peek—
A pause from being sharp, from being strong.
Now when I have a cold, I’m gently unmade,
And in the wreckage, softer thoughts are laid.

Now when I have a cold, the stars won’t come,
Just ceiling cracks I study in the dark.
My throat is home to a rasping, angry drum,
And dreams arrive in fits, a broken arc.
I cough like thunder in an empty hall,
Echoes of health now distant, out of reach.
The blankets weigh like judgment, over all,
A prison knit from wool the cat won’t teach.
I sip my tea, too hot, but barely feel,
My taste buds drowned beneath a mucus tide.
No spice, no salt—just cotton, cold and real,
Where flavor once danced boldly, deep inside.
Yet in this dullness, something starts to grow:
A tenderness for bodies, flawed and frail.
For how we ache, and rest, and softly know
That even kings must blow their nose, and fail.
Now when I have a cold, I touch the earth,
And learn the grace of temporary worth.

Now when I have a cold, I write in tissues,
Ink smeared by sneezes, damp with midnight sighs.
My keyboard clacks like teeth in Arctic missions,
While steam from mugs paints circles in the skies
Of my dim room. I watch the clock reverse,
Or so it seems—each hour stretched and thin.
The cough returns, a stubborn, barking verse,
A rhythm I can’t silence from within.
I miss the gym, the run, the open air,
Now trapped in bed, a creature of the damp.
My phone glows weak, a ghostly, floating flare,
Texting the world: I'm down, but not quite camp.
But in this slump, a different strength takes root—
The will to sip, to breathe, to simply be.
To find a joy in soup’s reviving flute,
And in the hush, a strange clarity.
Now when I have a cold, I stop, I see,
How slowing down can set the spirit free.

Now when I have a cold, the sky turns gray,
Not outside, but behind my aching eyes.
Each breath a wheeze, each word begins to fray,
As if my soul let out a series of sighs.
I blow my nose—a trumpet without pride,
A banner of surrender, soft and white.
The world keeps spinning, loud and undenied,
While I retreat into the hush of night.
My books lie open, pages half-consumed,
My thoughts too thick to follow any thread.
I watch the fan spin, dazed and slightly doomed,
A metronome above my fevered head.
But in this stillness, something starts to bloom—
A quiet love for being left behind.
For missing calls, for skipping every room,
For shedding all the roles I thought defined.
Now when I have a cold, I cease to strive,
And simply, slowly, learn how to survive.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
Now when I have a cold, the world slows down,

While tissues bloom like blossoms rare.
My breath is thick, my voice a croak,
A frog who’s lost his watery cloak.
Yet in this haze of sniffles deep,
I find a rhythm in the creep
Of time that stretches, soft and long,
A lullaby without a song.
Outside, the wind knocks on the pane,
But here, I drift through fevered rain,
Dreaming of forests, clean and cold,
Where pine trees whisper, sharp and bold.
Now when I have a cold, I see
The fragile grace of being weak—
A chance to rest, to breathe, to know
That even stillness helps us grow.

Now when I have a cold, I cough and sigh,
My nose runs like a river through December’s sky.
I wrap in scarves, I gulp down tea,
With lemon, honey—desperate glee.
My dog just stares with judging eyes,
As if my sneezes are a crime.
But in this mess of tissues, dread,
A strange kind of comfort settles in my head.
For once, I’m not required to be bright,
To laugh too loud or win the fight.
I’m excused, excused from being strong,
And for this moment, I belong
To quiet rooms and blankets deep,
Where even sorrow takes a nap.
Now when I have a cold, I find
Permission to just fall behind.

Now when I have a cold, the stars feel far,
My pillow holds the weight of war.
Each breath a battle, each cough a drum,
This fragile body overcome.
Yet in the ache, a truth takes hold—
We are not machines, but flesh and soul.
A virus hums beneath my skin,
A tiny force that pulls me in
From busy streets and endless tasks,
To face the quiet that I ask
But never take. Now, laid in bed,
I count the cracks above my head,
And wonder if, in being weak,
We sometimes glimpse what’s true and meek.

Now when I have a cold, I sip warm broth,
And listen to the ticking clock.
My thoughts are thick, my limbs like stone,
Yet I’m not quite alone.
For every sniffle, every chill,
Brings back the hush of childhood still—
My mother’s hand upon my brow,
A world reduced to then and now.
No emails, plans, or urgent calls,
Just blankets, books, and yawns and walls.
Now when I have a cold, I find
A simpler, slower, softer mind.

Now when I have a cold, I dream of flight,
Of soaring past the edge of night.
But here I lie, in bed, confined,
To coughs that rattle heart and mind.
Still, in this ache, a muse appears,
And whispers verses through my tears.
For poetry thrives in pain and rest,
In moments when we’re undressed
From pride and pace. Now, weak and slow,
I let the healing verses grow.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
Now when I have a cold, the world grows small,

Each breath a battle, nasal and forlorn,

I watch the rain sketch maps upon the pane,
And wonder if the sun will come again.
My books lie open, yet I read but two
Pages in hours—coughing breaks the view.
Even my dog seems cautious, keeps his space,
As if my germs have drawn a guarded lace
Around my chair. Yet in this quiet ache,

For in this hush, where motion slows to dust,
I learn the grace of simply being just…
A body resting, not a mind that’s bold—
Now when I have a cold.

Now when I have a cold, I speak in snuffles,
My nose a faucet, thoughts all stuffed and muffled.
I sip my tea like some enchanted brew,
And dream of tissues—endless, soft, and new.
My blanket’s armor, pillow my confidant,
I wage war with sneezes, dramatic, rampant.
Outside, the world runs fast, but I am slow,
A sniffling hermit in a febrile glow.
I text my friends in emoji—headache, chill,
A blue-faced ghost with tissues piled still.
Yet in this weakness, there’s a kind of peace,
A forced retreat where worries must release.
No deadlines matter, no urgent call,
Just throat lozenges and Netflix sprawl.
I watch the clock, yet time feels rearranged,
As fever paints my thoughts, slightly deranged.
And though I curse this virus, mean and old—
Now when I have a cold.

Now when I have a cold, I count my breaths,
Each one a fragile thread that life bequeaths.
I feel the weight of lungs, so damp and tight,
Like sails gone slack in unremembered night.
The mirror shows two eyes, both dull and red,
As if my soul had caught what my nose bled.
I write these lines with fingers slightly numb,
While silence hums a low, persistent drum.
I miss the taste of food, the scent of rain,
My senses dulled, my joy a minor strain.
But in this frailty, something starts to grow—
A tenderness I never planned to know.
For when the body falters, spirit speaks,
And sorrow turns to solace, slow and meek.
So let me cough, let phlegm and fever hold—
Now when I have a cold.

Now when I have a cold, I eat soup slow,
Watch steam rise like secrets I used to know.
My voice sounds foreign, raspy, low, and thin,
Like an old record skipping deep within.
I blow my nose like trumpeting a tune,
A symphony of snot beneath the moon.
I text my mom, she sends a remedy,
A recipe with ginger, bold and free.
I wrap in scarves, though summer fills the street,
My body lies, insists it’s sleet, not heat.
And though I ache, and though my head’s in fog,
There’s warmth in being gently, briefly, clogged.
For in this pause, I hear the house breathe too,
The fridge, the clock, the sighing floorboards—true.
A quiet kinship with all things that fold—
Now when I have a cold.

Now when I have a cold, I talk to germs,
Ask why they’ve chosen me for their concerns.
They don’t reply, just multiply with glee,
And turn my brain to porridge, thick and fee.
I dream in coughs, wake up with snorts and wheezes,
My dreams invaded by congested breezes.
I watch old films where heroes never sniffle,
And wonder how they dodge this annual griddle.
I drink lemon water, honey, garlic tea,
As if these potions hold the key to me.
My dog licks my hand, then backs away fast,
As if my aura’s labeled: “Sick at last.”
Yet in this mess, a truth begins to show—
That slowing down is not the worst woe.
There’s poetry in tissues, soft and bold—
Now when I have a cold.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
Now when I have a cold, the world turns slow,

I text in caps, ‘I’M FINE!’ I write,
Though clearly drowning in the night.
My cat just stares, unimpressed, aloof,
As if my fate is plain as proof.
Yet in this slump, a truth takes root—
We’re all just flesh and fragile fruit.
And when the fever starts to fade,
I’ll miss the quiet that the sickness made.

Now when I have a cold, I float in sheets,
A ghost among my own heartbeats.
My breath is thick, my head is dense,
A cloud of slow, thick recompense.
I hum a tune my throat won’t hold,
A melody gone slightly old.
The kettle sings, the windows weep,
While I count promises I can’t keep.
My phone buzzes with life outside,
But I’m too deep in flu to hide.
Yet in this hush, a calm takes flight—
The world keeps turning, soft and light.
And though I ache and cough and freeze,
There’s peace within these ailing knees.
For even colds, with all their toll,
Can cradle stillness in the soul.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
Now when I have a cold, the world grows still,
Wrapped in a shawl of quiet, thick and deep.
My breath a slow bellows, my thoughts uphill,
While shadows in the corners softly creep.
Steam from my cup ascends in wisps of prayer,
Condensing on the window, blurred and dim.
I watch the rain trace paths without a care,
Like mucus down the glass—a hymn to him,
The body’s humble work to purge and mend,
A temple under siege, yet standing tall.
The kettle sings, a friend I can depend,
While blankets hold me, gentle as a thrall.
I sip my tea, a monk in convalescence,
Grateful for the ache that teaches presence.

Now when I have a cold, I talk in snuffles,
A bear in flannel, grumbling through the day.
My nose runs rivers, cheeks are red as mussels,
And tissues pile like snowdrifts in disarray.
I cough like thunder, startle sleeping cats,
Blow my nose like a trumpet in a farce.
Yet laughter sneaks in, despite these stats,
This human mess we wear like second lark.
Soup steams like comfort, broth with love infused,
My dog licks snot and still adores my face.
There’s grace in snot, if you’re not confused—
A bond of germs and warmth in close embrace.
Now when I have a cold, I’m weak, yet whole,
A sniffling poet, rhyming from the soul.

Now when I have a cold, I dream in coughs,
Of distant lands where noses breathe with ease.
No phlegm to choke, no throat that painfully scoffs,
Just open air beneath eternal trees.
I am a knight with lance of Kleenex bold,
Defending sinuses from viral horde.
My cape? A scarf. My castle? Downy fold
Of quilt and pillow, whispering reward.
I wage soft war with teas and honeyed spells,
Hum melodies between each hacking fit.
The body battles, and my spirit dwells
In fragile peace, where healing thoughts are knit.
Now when I have a cold, I learn to rest,
And find in weakness, I am strangely blessed.

Now when I have a cold, I write in drips,
Like mucus down the pane of consciousness.
Each stanza snuffled, every metaphor slips
Into the bog of sniffled tenderness.
My keyboard sticky, nose a faucet wide,
I type with one hand, hold a tissue near.
Yet words still come, like phlegm I can’t hide,
A poet plagued, yet driven by some cheer.
For even sickness sings in rhythmic breath,
The ache, the cough, the steam, the aching head.
I rhyme through fever, flirt with certain death
Of boredom more than illness, truth be said.
Now when I have a cold, I find my voice—
A congested bard, still choosing to rejoice.

Now when I have a cold, I watch the wall,
Its cracks like rivers on a dusty map.
I count the ceiling’s flaws, hear the hall
Echo with silence, save a tissue’s snap.
My body hums a low and croaky tune,
A broken engine sputtering through night.
The moon appears, a cold and distant moon,
Shining on sickness with indifferent light.
I drink my water, swallow pills like prayers,
Feel fever flicker like a candle’s flame.
And in this stillness, unadorned, unpaired,
I whisper thanks for rest, for warmth, for name.
Now when I have a cold, I touch the real—
The quiet grace that only hurt can heal.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Stolen the bloom that graced my morning sky. / The golden sun of hope, once bright with truth, / Now fades behind the clouds where shadows lie. / No shield nor plea can stay his silent tread, / Nor youth’s bold cry arrest his steady pace. / Each moment lost, a dream left for the dead, / A fleeting breath erased without a trace. / Yet in the dusk, where memory takes flight, / I glimpse the echoes of what once was mine— / Not gone, but changed, transmuted into light / That warms the spirit, not the flesh or line. / Though Time may steal the face the glass once knew, / The soul endures, and love renews its hue.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Crept through the garden where my roses grew. / The petals fall, unheeded, into truth, / As seasons turn and skies grow cold and blue. / I marked not when the sapling lost its leaves, / Nor heard the whisper as my vigor fled. / Now in the mirror, what the past conceives / Is but a ghost of words once brightly said. / Yet in the stillness, wisdom starts to bloom, / A quieter grace, less eager, more aware. / Not all is lost beneath this waning moon— / Some joys grow deeper when the flash is bare. / Though youth departs on wings I cannot hold, / My heart still sings in stories yet untold.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Slipped through my hands like sand at ebbtide’s call. / I chased the sun, but now I know the truth— / It was the dawn that slipped away, not all. / My laughter rings, though softer than before, / My steps more slow, yet steady on the road. / The dreams I had, I carry still, and more— / They’ve deepened like a river, not eroded. / For though the fire of youth may dim and wane, / A gentler flame now warms the growing night. / The years have taken, yes, but not in vain— / They’ve given me the stars to guide my sight. / So let Time steal what hours he may claim; / My soul remains, unbound by age or name.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Turned summer’s blaze to embers in the breast. / I searched for joy in motion, noise, and truth, / But found it quiet, in stillness, and in rest. / The mirror shows a map of where I’ve been— / Each line a tale, each gray a lesson learned. / The boy I was would not believe this skin, / Yet might admire the fire that still has burned. / Not all is lost when vigor starts to fade; / Some gifts arrive too late for youth to see. / The love I now possess was never made / In haste, but shaped by years of being free. / So Time may steal the bloom, the leap, the song— / But not the wisdom where I now belong.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Stolen the light that danced upon my brow. / I did not feel the slow, insidious sleuth, / Until the bloom was gone, the bough bent low. / The songs I sang now echo far away, / Like birds that fled before the coming frost. / I watch the dusk replace the brightening day, / And count the treasures that my life has lost. / Yet in the hush, a different music plays— / A deeper tone, a calm I never knew. / The heart that raced now finds its steady gaze, / And sees the world in softer, truer view. / Though Time may claim the spring, the leap, the flame, / It cannot touch the essence of my name.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Stolen the bloom that graced my early morn; / Each fleeting hour, a whisper, not in truth, / Leaves me with shadows where bright hopes were born. / The spring of life, once rich with songs and fire, / Now yields to autumn's melancholy hue; / The dreams that danced like sparks now sink entire, / As colder winds bid fervent passions few. / Yet though my face no longer holds the grace / That once the mirror praised with gentle light, / I find a calm within this slower pace— / A wisdom carved from both the day and night. / For Time may steal the face, the form, the flame, / But not the soul that bears its quiet name.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Whispered its name and dimmed my morning light; / Once I pursued the echoes of the truth, / Now I observe the stars from quieter night. / The fire that burned within my eager chest / Has softened to a glow that understands; / No longer racing, but by choice, I rest, / Held by the grace of aging, not by hands. / The years have carved a face I barely know, / But in its lines, a thousand tales reside; / Each wrinkle sings of joy, of loss, of woe, / Of love that time could neither take nor hide. / So though the thief has come and claimed its due, / My soul remains, and that was never youth.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Stolen the blush that crowned my early days; / The world once spun with endless hope and truth, / Now moves in slower, more reflective ways. / I once believed that moments would stay near, / That joy would linger, love would never fade; / But seasons change, and every face we revere / Must bow to time’s unyielding masquerade. / Yet in this quiet, something starts to bloom— / A deeper sense of peace I never knew; / Not in the light, but in the gathering gloom, / My heart has learned what it was meant to do. / So let the thief take what it thinks is gain, / My soul outlasts the shadow and the rain.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Snuffed out the torch I carried through the night; / The dreams I carved with passion and with truth / Now rest like fossils, buried out of sight. / I measured life in victories and songs, / In loves that burned and friendships forged in flame; / But seasons passed, and all those rhythms wrongs, / And left me with a slower, quieter name. / Yet in the stillness, something starts to bloom— / Not bright, perhaps, but rooted deep and real. / The silence speaks of comfort in the gloom, / And how the heart can softly learn to heal. / Though youth is gone, its embers still ignite / A gentler, wiser, more enduring light.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Hath stolen dawn’s first blush from eager eyes,
And turned the fire of passion into truth,
As summer’s bloom to autumn’s soft demise.
Each hour a whisper through the trembling leaves,
A breath that bends the grass but leaves no trace.
I count the days not by what joy achieves,
But by the dreams that time could not erase.
Yet in this quiet march, a gift remains—
Not strength of limb or glory of the face,
But wisdom etched in slow-healing veins,
And love grown deeper in time’s steady grace.
The thief returns what he could not destroy:
The soul’s calm light, no season can alloy.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept through the chambers where my visions played,
Snuffed out the candles of unmeasured truth,
And dimmed the colors hope so boldly made.
Once swift of foot, I raced the rising sun,
Now walk with shadows lengthening behind.
What I once owned, I find I have outrun,
And what I sought, I’ve left undefined.
Yet in the hush, a gentler rhythm sings—
Not loss alone, but lessons softly learned.
Time steals the bloom, but gives the weight of wings,
And hands me peace for which I never yearned.
So let him take; I yield with quiet breath,
For age, too, cradles triumphs over death.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Stolen the boldness of my midnight calls,
The reckless laughter, fearless in its truth,
The weightless steps that bounded over walls.
Now every mirror holds a stranger’s gaze,
With lines that map the seasons I’ve withstood.
The future, once a road through golden days,
Now feels like walking through a quiet wood.
But in this hush, a deeper voice takes root—
Not loud, but firm, not swift, but sure and kind.
Though youth departs, the soul remains resolute,
And love endures beyond the reach of time.
So let the thief come; I have more to give
Than years alone could ever take and live.

Now listens to the moon and hums in June.
I counted moments like a miser’s gold,

Ambition’s flame grew cold before it rolled

But in the silence, I have come to know
A different rhythm, steady and profound.
The seeds I planted long ago still grow,
And grace now walks on once-unsteady ground.
So though the years have taken what they may,

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,

What once was boundless now is tempered, lost,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

responses.text:
Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,
Through the mist, the morning’s sigh.
Hush, the silence softly creeping,
Breaks beneath the lark’s low cry.
Your cloak is damp with dew and dreaming,
Your hands still clenched in midnight’s hold.
But see—the sun, in golden streaming,
Unfurls its banner, bright and bold.
No more the stars, no more the quiet,
The world now stirs with urgent breath.
Arise, for duty stands defiant,
And calls you from the arms of death.
Not with drums or blaring trumpet,
But in light so soft and thin,
It gilds the path you must run up it,
And bids the night’s reprieve to end.
So rise, not with curse or sorrow,
But with resolve both calm and deep.
The dawn will greet you on the morrow,
And watch the promises you keep.

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,
A silver thread across the sky.
No time for rest, no time for weeping,
The fields of fate are drawing nigh.
Your rifle leans against the bramble,
Your dreams still caught in yester’s flame.
The world, once dark, now starts to grapple
With coming light and whispered name.
They called you once a child of summer,
With laughter loud and eyes so wide.
Now duty marks your brow with number,
And shadows stretch with every stride.
Yet in this hush, before the thunder,
Before the clash, the cry, the fall,
There lies a moment—soft, unbounded—
Where peace may touch you, if but small.
So wake, not to the sound of orders,
But to the breath of earth renewed.
The sun will warm your weary shoulders,
And light the path you never knew.
Soldier, the dawn has come to meet you,
With neither pity nor disdain.
It sees the man the war has made,
And greets your soul by name.

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,
Through shattered tents and silent guns.
The night has wept, the stars have faltered,
Now morning treads on broken drums.
Your eyes, once closed to pain and distance,
Now flicker open, slow and sore.
The world returns with quiet insistence,
Demanding all it asked before.
No fanfare greets your reawakening,
No banner flaps, no bugle’s call.
Just mist that clings like old remembering,
And footsteps fading down the wall.
You rise not strong, but unrelenting,
A shadow draped in yesterday.
The past still hums, the future’s pending,
But here, now, you must face the day.
For every dawn that dares to brighten
Is both a gift and a demand.
It lifts the soul, yet leaves it tightened
With duty’s unforgiving hand.
So stand, though every limb resents it,
Though memory pulls you back to sleep.
The light has come, and it presents it:
The choice to walk, or lie, and weep.

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,
A timid glow on frost-strewn ground.
The night has kept its vigil, weeping,
But dawn has slipped without a sound.
Your breath still clouds in ghostly spirals,
Your heart recalls the dreams you fled.
The world, once dark, now softly narrows
To steps ahead, to words unsaid.
They told you war would bring you glory,
That honor gleamed on every blade.
But now you know a different story—
Of silence, loss, and debts unpaid.
Still, in this hush, a truth is dawning:
That courage isn’t loud or grand,
But in the choice to keep on walking,
With empty hands and heart unmanned.
So rise, not for the cause or nation,
But for the ones who did not wake.
Let every breath be their narration,
Let every step their promise make.
The sun now climbs, the shadows thin.
Soldier, the light is pulling you in.

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,
A blush of rose on ashen skies.
The night has gone, its secrets keeping,
But morning wears a different guise.
Your boots are caked with mud and sorrow,
Your pack still bears the weight of years.
Yet see—beyond the hill’s dark furrow,
A golden promise now appears.
No trumpet sounds, no general rallies,
Just birds that sing as if no war.
The earth renews, while man still mallets
The fragile peace it longs for.
And you, who’ve walked through fire and thunder,
Who’ve seen the worst that men can do,
Now face a dawn no bomb could sunder,
A light that makes you feel untrue.
For how can beauty still be blooming
Where blood once soaked the trampled grass?
Yet there it is—the sun still grooming
The world, as if the war would pass.
So wake, not to the call of battle,
But to the chance of being free.
The dawn does not demand your rattle—

The canteen’s warm, the rifle’s cold,
Your breath a cloud against the gray.
Another story to be told
When night returns and words betray.
But for now, the dawn is calling,
Not with hope, but grim embrace.
You rise — not fearing, not appalled —
And step into war’s waiting face.

Soldier, wake — the day is peeping,
Crimson streaks across the hill.
Campfires fade, their embers weeping,
As the world grows hushed and still.
Not with peace, but tense expectancy,
Breath held close in armored chest.
This dawn is not for joy or decency,
But duty’s call, put to the test.

The sergeant’s voice, a low command,
Boots crunch gravel, steel on stone.
A letter tucked in trembling hand,
Unsent, addressed to one now gone.
Yet still he moves, as others do,
Lining up beneath the sky.
Each face a world of quiet, true,
Of love left behind, of dreams that die.

The wind stirs flags in silent plea,
For those who’ll fall before noon.
No fanfare for their legacy,
Just names etched under fading moon.
But in this light, so soft, so fleeting,
Lies a courage forged in night.
Soldier, wake — your heart still beating,
March into the coming light.

Soldier, wake — the day is peeping,
Through the pines where shadows play.
Not with joy, but silence keeping
All the words you cannot say.
Your canteen leaks a silver trickle,
Morning mist clings to your sleeve.
The world feels thin, like ancient fickle
Dreams you can no longer believe.

You lace your boots with practiced motion,
Check your rifle, clean and cold.
No need for speech, no grand devotion —
Just the weight of years untold.
Somewhere far, a bird is singing,
In a land untouched by war.
Its song feels like a wound still stinging,
Of a peace you can’t ignore.

The line assembles, grim and quiet,
Eyes downcast, yet spirits high.
Not for conquest, not for riot,
But to live, to breathe, to try.
So rise, soldier, meet the dawning,
Let the light fall on your face.
Though the night was long and yawning,
You endure — in love and grace.

Soldier, wake — the day is peeping,
Faint and shy behind the trees.
No fanfare, no bells are pealing,
Just the rustle of the breeze.
Your blanket’s thin, the ground is stony,
But sleep has fled with night’s last gleam.
Now stands the hour, stark and lonely,
Lit by duty’s steady beam.

A comrade coughs, another sighs,
Someone hums a tune from home.
In these small sounds, the spirit flies
Back to places far from foam
And gunfire. Yet you must return,
To the present, sharp and clear.
The lesson every dawn must learn:
Courage wears a face of fear.

You rise, adjust your weighted gear,
Feel the weight of all you guard.
Not for fame, nor praise, nor cheer,
But because it must be hard.
So forward, soldier, step by step,
Into light that knows no name.
The world will never fully get
The depth from which you came.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

responses.text:

Soldier, wake - the day is near,

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,

A sweetheart’s kiss, a child’s small hand tied

Fog still clings, a spectral form,

You stir beneath your tattered coat,

Between the living and the gone,
Where silence sings a mournful song.
The canteen’s dented, rifle cold,
Yet in your chest, a story told
By beating heart that will not yield—
A harvest sown on broken field.
You rise, not for glory, but for those
Who sleep beneath the foreign snows.
With every breath, their names you keep,
As daylight climbs the shattered steep.
Soldier, wake - the world is waking,
And in your eyes, its future’s making.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Through cracks in clouds where nightmares leap.
Your eyelids flutter, heavy, sore,
Dreaming not of war, but of the shore—
Of tides that roll with gentle might,
And stars that guide through endless night.
But boots are laced, your pack is tight,
Another march into the light.
No fanfare marks this morning’s birth,
Just rustling leaves and thoughts of worth.
What does it mean to stand and fight
When peace seems but a fleeting light?
Yet here you are, with breath and bone,
Determined not to face alone
The rising sun, the coming test,
The quiet courage in your chest.
For every step the darkness flees,
Not by grand acts, but small decays
Of fear, replaced by steady will.
Soldier, wake - climb the hill.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
A blush of rose where night was creeping.
Your helmet dented, coat worn thin,
A world reborn begins within.
Not with thunder, not with flame,
But in the softness of your name
Whispered by wind through trembling trees,
Carried on morning’s gentle breeze.
You stretch your limbs, recall the dream—
A mother’s voice, a childhood stream.
Now duty calls with gentler tone,
Not to destroy, but to atone.
The battlefield may scar the land,
But dawn redeems what blood has banned.
Each breath you take, a quiet vow
To live, not just to fight or bow.
So rise, not as a blade unsheathed,
But as the man the war believed
Could still love light, could still believe—
Soldier, wake - and start to grieve,
Then heal.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
While frost still grips the ground, unyielding.
Your breath a ghost in morning’s air,
A world suspended, stark and bare.
No orders bark, no whistle screams,
Just silence spun from broken dreams.
You blink at sky of ashen gray,
Another night has slipped away.
Your fingers brush a photo creased—
A face loved, lost, and long released.
Yet still you carry that soft smile,
Like distant sun through smoke and bile.
The crows take flight from skeletal trees,
Announcing hours brought to their knees
By time and tread of weary feet.
The war is cold, the front’s heartbeat
A slow pulse under frozen soil,
Where hope lies buried, yet recoils
And pushes up through cracked despair—
A crocus braving winter’s glare.
Soldier, wake - though shadows cling,
The dawn still dares to whisper: *sing*.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

responses.text:
Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Through the mist, the dawn is creeping.
Hark! The bugle's call resounds,
Echoing where silence once was found.

Your cloak of night now sheds the dew,
Dreams of home must bid adieu.
The fields once green now scarred by flame,
Bear your name, your silent claim.

Your hands, though weary, grip the steel,
Not for glory, but what is real—
A promise made beneath the moon,
To guard the cradle, shield the noon.

The sky blushes with tender light,
A fragile peace, a fleeting right.
Yet you rise, not with a cry,
But steady breath beneath the sky.

For duty walks where shadows fall,
And courage stands though others call
For rest, for love, for sweet release—
You stand your ground, the soul of peace.

So wake, O soldier, meet the morn,
Though weary, torn, and battle-worn.
Each step you take, the world keeps breathing,
For love like yours keeps death from seething.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Through fractured tents and silence weeping.
Steel grows warm beneath the sun’s first glance,
As if the earth itself takes a stance.

Your eyes, half-shut with dreams of wheat,
Of children’s laughter, soft and sweet,
Are torn away by distant drum—
A world not done, a kingdom numb.

You rise, not bold, but burdened, slow,
With ghosts that in your footsteps go.
Each name you knew, now etched in stone,
Whispers through the wind alone.

Yet still you stand, not for a crown,
But for the soil, the sleeping town.
Not for the flag, but for the hand
That plants the seed in conquered land.

The morning paints the sky in gold,
A story not yet fully told.
You breathe, you march, you do not yield—
A quiet force upon the field.

So wake, O soldier, face the flame,
And bear the light, though none proclaim.
For dawn returns not with a song,
But with the right to carry on.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Over trenches where shadows are sleeping.
Frost still clings to your rifle’s edge,
And sorrow rests on every ledge.

You stir, not from command or fear,
But from a voice that draws you near—
A mother’s call, a lover’s sigh,
Beneath a vast, unblinking sky.

The world is cold, the path unclear,
But duty hums in every ear.
You lace your boots with trembling hands,
And rise to meet the morning’s demands.

No fanfare marks your slow ascent,
No crowd to cheer, no time to vent.
Just breath, and step, and silent prayer,
For those no longer standing there.

The sun ascends, a golden tear,
Illuminating loss and fear.
Yet in your chest, a steady beat—
A pulse that will not know defeat.

So wake, O soldier, take the hill,
With courage forged against all will.
For every dawn that dares to break,
Is born from choices you now make.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Through cracks in clouds, the light is seeping.
Your eyelids flutter, heavy with dreams,
Of rivers wide and silent streams.

But war does not allow retreat,
Nor let the soul find calm or seat.
A comrade shakes your aching frame,
And whispers, 'Brother, time to claim

The field once more, the fight anew,
Though every bone in you feels through
With longing for a softer bed,
And words not shouted, but softly said.'

You rise, not proud, but pained and plain,
A man shaped by relentless rain.
Your uniform, a second skin,
Worn thin by where the wars begin.

The sky now glows with amber hue,
A beauty born from morning’s due.
And though your heart may break and bend,
You walk—because you must, my friend.

For peace is not a gift, but earned,
By those whose fires have long since burned.
So wake, O soldier, face the day,
And keep the dark at bay.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Across the ridge where silence is keeping.
Mist rolls low like whispered prayers,
Floating through the vacant chairs

Of homes far off, where loved ones wait,
Unsure of fate, of love, of date.
Your breath is smoke in morning’s chill,
A fleeting trace of mortal will.

You rise, not cheered, not crowned, not known,
Just one among the flesh and bone
That stands between the night and light,
Between the wrong and what is right.

No anthem sounds, no banner flies,
Just open wounds and hollow eyes.
Yet in your chest, a spark remains—
A quiet fire that still sustains.

The sun now climbs, a golden thread,
Weaving hope where death has tread.
You lift your head, you face the flame,
And breathe the world back into name.

So wake, O soldier, take your stand,
With steady heart and calloused hand.
For every dawn that dares to bloom,
Is carried forth by those in gloom.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

responses.text:

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,

You stir beneath your tattered coat,

Recalling words from distant note—

But time allows no long farewell,

No glory here in blood and mud,

So rise, brave soul, though weary, sore,

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,

But now the order cuts the air,

So rise, O soldier, strong and grim,

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,

You rise from earth both cold and thin,

Beneath the glare of rising moon,

You fasten gear with practiced hands,
Recall the faces left behind—
A daughter’s eyes, a lover’s strands,
Now memories entwined with time.
Yet forward lies the field of fate,
No turning back, no second chance;

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,

You stretch beneath a sky half-known,

But now the bugle splits the hush,

You rise, not bold, but resolute,

For though the dawn may not bring peace,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

responses.text:
Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Through the mist, the silver light.
Fields once red now lie in sleeping,
Shrouded deep in morning white.

Hear the lark call from the thicket,
Softly singing songs of old.
Dreams of home on every ticket,
Memories braver than the bold.

Boots are laced with frost and duty,
Back still bent from silent nights.
Yet in heart there burns a beauty—
Hope that outlives war's long fights.

Rise, not to the beat of drumming,
Nor the shout that calls to pain,
But to life, to love, to coming
Spring that will not ask in vain.

For though trenches carve the meadow,
And the guns still curse the sky,
There is peace beyond the shadow—
Soldier, live. The dawn is nigh.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
A blush of gold on ashen ground.
No more the watch that silence keeps,
The quiet scream, the battle's sound.

Your cloak is worn, your hands are weary,
Marked by frost and far-off flame.
Yet in your chest, a pulse still cheery,
Whispers gently every name.

Of comrades lost beneath the moon,
Of letters read a thousand times.
The mother's tear, the lover's tune—
These are the rhythms, these the rhymes.

Now lift your eyes to skies unbroken,
Where clouds like banners drift and part.
Not all that’s spoken is a token
Of war—some words rebuild the heart.

So rise, not to the call of cannons,
But to the breath of coming spring.
For even in the darkest fashions,
Hope is the song that dawn will sing.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,

Your rifle rests, your helmet dented,

But time, though scarred, is not invented
For endless watch or silent sleep.

The world still turns beyond the wire,
Where children laugh and rivers run.
And though you've walked through hell's own pyre,
The rising sun says, 'You are one.'

One soul among the brave and broken,
One voice beneath the open blue.
Not all is lost, not all is token
Of death and dread—you're living, true.

So open eyes that war has narrowed,
Let morning warm your frozen cheek.
The earth still sings, though softly harrowed—
Soldier, it's time. The world feels weak,

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,

For in that light, so pale and tender,

The war may claim both time and motion,

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
At the highways of woes, where shadows stretch long,
And the wind carries echoes of forgotten song,
I walk with a burden, a heart full of rust,
Tracing dreams turned to dust.
Each mile a memory, sharp as a thorn,
Of love once blooming, now tattered and torn.
Trucks roar past like the years slipping free,
Blinding me with their indifferent speed.
Yet in the silence between each sound,
A whisper persists from the lost and the drowned—
Not of despair, but a quiet refrain:
Even sorrow can ease into gentle rain.
And though the road climbs through storm and through night,
There’s a light in the distance, not born but alight—
A flicker, a hope, soft and low,
At the highways of woes, we still learn to go.

At the highways of woes, the asphalt weeps,
Beneath the weight of a thousand lost sheep.
Tires hum dirges on cracked concrete veins,
While grief rides shotgun through acid rain.
No signs mark the exits, no rest in sight,
Just neon ghosts in the pale moonlight.
Here, the broken refuel with bitter air,
And headlights carve prayers no one will hear.
I passed a man dancing in a gas-station glow,
Laughing like freedom was all that he’d know—
A rebel against the silent decree,
That sorrow is all life can be.
So I rolled down my window and sang with his voice,
Let the pain find a rhythm, let grief have a choice.
For even in exile, in depths we descend,
At the highways of woes, we can still be friends
With the parts of us wounded, the scars that we own—
And carry them forward, no longer alone.

At the highways of woes, the sky hangs low,
A bruise-colored dusk where no soft winds blow.
Tarmac stretches, a serpent uncoiled,
With stories of hearts that were shattered and spoiled.
I drive with no destination, just miles of gray,
Counting streetlights like prayers gone astray.
Each glow a ghost of a hope once believed,
Now flickering faint, barely perceived.
Yet in the rearview, a dawn starts to rise,
Painting the dark with reluctant skies.
Not bright, not bold, but a whisper of hue—
A promise that even the lost break through.
For every tear spilled on this desolate run,
There’s a song being forged from what can’t be undone.
And though the road bends through sorrow and strain,
At the highways of woes, we are not in vain.
We carry the weight, yet we carry the light,
One breath, one mile, into morning’s first sight.

At the highways of woes, the engines moan,
Like souls dragging chains through a land of stone.
No trees, no rivers, just pylons and signs
That point to places lost in old rhymes.
I met a traveler with eyes full of years,
Who spoke not in words, but in silent tears.
He handed me a map drawn in smoke and regret,
Saying, "All roads here lead to what you left."
But I folded it gently and placed it away,
For I’ve learned that grief, too, can pave its own way.
So I drive not to flee, but to face and to feel,
Let the ache be a truth that I slowly reveal.
And somewhere between the exhaust and the stars,
I find a strange peace beneath prison-bar
Clouds—because even in exile and night,
At the highways of woes, there’s still love in sight,
Not as a rescue, nor as a release,
But as a companion that grants us some peace.

At the highways of woes, the radio hums
A staticky tune where no melody comes.
I tap the wheel to a rhythm of pain,
Counting losses like exit signs in the rain.
Each mile marker a year I can’t reclaim,
Each overpass shadows a whispered name.
But then—a sparrow, small, on a wire so bare,
Singing like nothing in the world could compare.
How can it sing in this wasteland of gray?
Perhaps it knows what I’ve yet to say:
That sorrow is vast, yes, and deep as the sea,
But life isn’t measured by where we must be.
It’s in tiny rebellions, in breath, in a note,
In driving through darkness with hope in the throat.
So I roll down the glass and let silence expand,
And carry that sparrow’s brave song in my hand.
For even when lost on this road of deep sighs,
At the highways of woes, beauty still flies.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
At the highways of woes, where shadows stretch long,
And echoes of sorrow in silence belong,
I walked with a burden stitched into my chest,
A heart full of questions with no one to confess.
Each mile a memory, each signpost a name,
Of loves turned to ashes, of passion gone lame.
Trucks roared past like the years I have lost,
Their headlights like phantoms, their cargo the cost
Of choices made blindly in twilight and fear,
Of whispers unheeded, of voices too near
And yet never heard. But deep in the night,
A star cracked in two, spilling silvered light.
And I realized the road, though paved with regret,
Still leads—still moves—still offers a bet
On dawn at the edge of the world’s heavy rim.
Even grief must surrender to morning’s first hymn.

At the highways of woes, the asphalt breathes pain,
Where tire marks tell stories no poets explain.
Here, the wind carries sighs from a thousand past lives,
Of drivers who fled but could never arrive.
No exits, no bridges, no rest stops in sight,
Just the hum of the dark and the crush of the night.
Each lane is a wound, each mirror a ghost,
Reflecting the pieces we’ve lost and the most
We pretend we don’t miss: a laugh, a soft hand,
The scent of old rain on forgotten land.
Yet somewhere ahead, past the fumes and the glare,
A flicker—a signal—that someone still cares.
Not to rescue, but walk, step by aching step,
Through the storm of the miles we are cursed to accept.
For even in sorrow, the engine still turns,
And the soul, though it burns, still yearns.

At the highways of woes, the sky wears a bruise,
And the stars are too tired to offer much news.
I drove with no map, just the ache in my bones,
And the static of thoughts over fractured phone tones.
Each mile marker whispered a name I once knew,
Now buried in silence, in fog, in the blue
Of rearview regrets that I can’t leave behind.
No mercy in speed, no relief to be find.
But then—just a glimmer—a roadside café,
Where a stranger poured coffee and didn’t look away.
No words, just a nod, as if saying, 'I know.'
And for one fleeting moment, the engine slowed.
Not healing, not hope, but a breath, just a pause,
A truce in the war of the open-road flaws.
Sometimes salvation’s not wings or a prayer,
But a warm cup, a glance, someone choosing to care.

At the highways of woes, the lines blur to gray,
And time drives in circles, refusing to stay.
I followed the signs, though they led me to rust,
To bridges half-collapsed and dreams turned to dust.
Each turnpike a trial, each toll a new tear,
Each overpass looming with ghosts I hold dear.
I screamed at the sky, but the wind took my voice,
Left stranded with echoes and fractured device.
Yet deep in the dashboard, a song started low,
A melody buried from long ago.
It wasn’t a fix, nor a promise of peace,
But a rhythm that matched my unsteady release.
And for three short verses, I wasn’t alone—
The music, the road, and a heart finding tone.
Not joy, not redemption, but something like grace:
The courage to keep on, at whatever the pace.

At the highways of woes, the air tastes of rust,
And the moon is a witness that doesn’t adjust.
I passed broken down trucks with their hoods open wide,
Like hearts left unshielded, too raw to hide.
No GPS guides you through sorrow like this—
Just the pulse of the pavement and ache in your wrists.
I thought of retreat, of reversing the gear,
But the past is a wall, and the future unclear.
Then a fox darted across with a flick of its flame,
A spark in the dark, not afraid of the frame
Of night and of distance. It vanished too fast,
But its moment left ripples that anchored my past.
Not every road ends where it’s meant to begin.
Sometimes, just to witness is where we win.
And though grief has its lanes, its detours, its tolls,
We carry the light in the cracks of our souls.

Yet in the distance, a flicker takes form—
A roadside diner, defiant, warm.
Steam curls from a cup, a voice calls my own,
And for just one moment, I’m no longer alone.
For even the highways of deepest despair
Can harbor a grace in the midnight air.
Not all is lost when the path runs dark;
Sometimes, salvation wears the face of a lark,
Or a waitress’s smile, or the hum of the road,
Reminding the soul that it still can hope.
So I drive on, not knowing the end,
But trusting the journey, and calling it friend.

At the highways of woes, the asphalt weeps,
Beneath the weight of broken dreams and silent keeps.
Tires whisper secrets to the cracked concrete,
Of lovers departed and hearts incomplete.
The guardrails tremble with stories untold,
Of hands once held tight, now numb and cold.
Fog drapes the overpass like a shroud,
Hiding the cries of the desperate and proud.
Yet in the median, a wildflower grows—
Small, defiant, where no kindness goes.
Its petals, bruised, still turn to the sky,
As if to say, 'Even here, I can try.'
A semitruck blares, a sudden roar,
But the flower bends, then stands once more.
And I, who have wandered this road so long,
Find strength in the frail, the fleeting, the wrong.
For pain is a passage, not just an end,
And healing begins where we choose to bend.
So I walk the highway with grief in my chest,
But hope in my step, and breath in my chest.

At the highways of woes, the night is thick,
A syrup of sorrow, dense and quick.
Neon signs stutter in the rain’s cold glare,
Advertising solace, but offering despair.
I pass rest stops where ghosts convene,
Sipping coffee from chipped, eternal scenes.
A hitchhiker nods, face half in shade,
His eyes hold the toll that the journey has paid.
We don’t speak—we know the same ache,
The kind that no map or mile can slake.
Yet in the rearview, a dawn starts to rise,
Not golden, but gray, with hesitant skies.
It doesn’t promise an end to the pain,
But merely suggests we might live through the rain.
And so I press on, not toward a prize,
But because motion itself is a form of wise.
For to stop is to drown in the depth of the night,
But to drive is to wrestle with fading light.
At the highways of woes, I am not free,
But I am moving—and that must be.
A breath, a blink, a gear shift, a sigh—
I am still here. I am passing by.

At the highways of woes, the wind sings low,
A dirge for the lost and the love let go.
Concrete snakes through valleys of gray,
Where even the birds have flown away.
I drive with the radio off, no sound,
Just the drum of my heart on unholy ground.
Each exit sign mocks with names I once knew—
Places of joy, now stained through and through.
But then—a melody, faint, in the air,
A child’s laughter, light as a prayer.
It spills from a car with windows rolled down,
A family, singing, heading to some small town.
Their joy is brief, just a flash in the gloom,
Yet it pierces the dark like a sudden bloom.
And I realize, though the road is unkind,
No soul walks it fully ungraced by light.
Even sorrow has seams where grace slips in—
A song, a sunrise, a stranger’s grin.
So I roll down my window and let in the breeze,
And whisper, 'I’m still here. I’m still on my knees.'
But the highway hums back, 'Keep going. Just be.'

At the highways of woes, the stars refuse to shine,
Oblivious constellations in a cold, black design.
Tarmac stretches like a scar through the land,
A monument built by a grief-stricken hand.
I pass billboards with faces that used to be mine,
Smiling in ink, frozen in time.
Now just ghosts in the glare of oncoming beams,
Haunting the edges of fractured dreams.
A diner light glows—a bruise in the dark—
Where time moves slow and the clocks left their mark.
I sit at the counter, no words to confess,
Just coffee and silence, a kind of finesse.
The waitress, old eyes, knows the look all too well—
She pours without asking, rings a faint bell.
No cure, no fix, no grand revelation,
Just presence, and space, and a shared desolation.
And somehow, that’s enough for tonight.
Not healing, but holding on with all my might.
For the highway won’t end, and the pain won’t cease,
But I’m not alone in this aching release.
At the highways of woes, I am known,
And that, for now, is a seed newly sown.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
At the highways of woes, where shadows stretch long,
And echoes of sorrow in silence belong,
I walked with a burden, heart full of rust,
Beneath skies that remembered the dust.

Each mile a memory, sharp as a thorn,
Of promises broken and love once worn.
Trucks roared past like ghosts in the night,
Their headlights revealing no hope, only fright.

Yet in the distance, a flicker, a glow—
A roadside diner where kind strangers go.
Steam on the window, a laugh, a song—
A haven where hearts haven’t gone wrong.

So I paused, took breath, let my shoulders fall,
And shared my grief over coffee and call.
For even on highways of endless despair,
Compassion still blooms in the thin morning air.

And though the road winds through storm and through frost,
No traveler is ever entirely lost.
For every wound has a witness, it seems,
And even grief walks in shared, human dreams.

At the highways of woes, the asphalt weeps,
Where the wind carries secrets the night refuses to keep.
Tire marks etch stories of those who passed through,
Chasing dreams that never quite grew.

Abandoned suitcases by the guardrail lie,
Each holding a name, a sigh, a goodbye.
Flickering signs offer rest, but none deliver,
Just neon illusions that fade in the river.

A hitchhiker stands with eyes full of rain,
No destination, just escape from the pain.
I offer no words, just a seat and the road,
Two ghosts sharing silence beneath a cold load.

We drive through the dark, where the moon barely gleams,
Bound by the weight of unspoken dreams.
No map can chart where our sorrows will go,
Only the rhythm of wheels in the snow.

And still, in the hum of the engine’s low moan,
There’s music—a pulse not quite over and done.
For even in woe, there’s a path we can trace,
A fleeting connection, a moment of grace.

At the highways of woes, the sky bleeds gray,
Where time slows down and hearts go astray.
Each lane a life, each exit a choice,
Some born of chaos, some born of noise.

I saw a woman dance in the rain,
On a bridge where regrets ran like a vein.
She twirled with no music, no one to see,
Just the thunder’s drum and the willow’s plea.

A trucker leaned out, tossed her a rose,
Plastic and faded, but still it glows.
No words were spoken, just a nod, a smile,
A second of warmth in a thousand miles.

This is the truth the highways reveal:
Sorrow is vast, but never surreal.
We carry it openly, raw and exposed,
Like scars on the skin of those we’ve lost.

And though the road forks into endless night,
We drive with the stars as our only light.
For even in woe, we find our own pace,
And love lingers still in the highways of grace.

At the highways of woes, the engines growl,
As headlights pierce through the ash-colored shroud.
Each car a coffin, each driver a shade,
Haunting the route that their choices have made.

I followed a shadow that looked like my name,
Through tunnels where silence is never the same.
It whispered of failures, of bridges burned down,
Of love turned to ice in a forgotten town.

A crow on a signpost cackled with glee,
As I knelt on the shoulder and set sorrow free.
Not with a scream, but a soft, steady breath,
Letting go of the weight that led me to death.

Then dawn cracked open like an egg of gold,
And the highway shimmered, no longer so cold.
For even in darkness, there’s warmth in the fight,
And every long road leads somewhere in light.

So I rose with the sun, no longer in chains,
Leaving grief in the ditches, like old license plates.
For the highways of woes are not meant to stay—
Just passages guiding us back to the day.

At the highways of woes, the air tastes of rust,
And the pavement hums with a grief-covered crust.
No billboards here selling joy or relief,
Just endless asphalt and private grief.

I walked with a suitcase full of old tears,
And a photo of someone lost through the years.
Each step echoed loud in the hollowed-out night,
Where even the stars hide their light.

Then a bus pulled over, its doors opened wide,
An old woman inside with nowhere to hide.
"Get in," she said, "this road’s not for walking.
The soul needs motion, not just silent talking."

So I rode through the dark, past fields of dead corn,
Where ghosts of the broken are forever forlorn.
But in that bus, with its flickering light,
We shared our stories into the night.

And though the highway still groaned with despair,
We found fleeting peace in the act of being there.
For sorrow, when shared, becomes something less—
A burden divided, a kind of success.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:

At the highways of woes, the wind speaks low,

For every shadow the headlights cast,

Time doesn’t heal, but it lets you drive,

So press the gas, though tears may fall,

At the highways of woes, we learn to steer,
Not from the pain, but through it, clear.

At the highways of woes, the pavement cracks,

A crow takes flight with a rusted ring,

Gas stations flicker with neon lies,

But in the backseat, a journal lies open,

Poems scribbled in midnight blue,

For grief is not a road to end,

responses.text:

At the highways of woes, the rain falls hard,

I stand beside the guardrail’s edge,

At the highways of woes, I kneel,

Yet in my chest, a quiet flame,

At the highways of woes, I choose

At the highways of woes, the silence screams,

At the highways of woes, I see
